text: That is funny. Radiation Transfer is about how CO2 works as a greenhouse gas. Anyone who knows anything about physics or has technical common sense would know that CO2 isn't causing much if any of the recent modest warming observed in our climate. Using Schwarzschild equations, If you double the CO2 concentration from the current 410 ppm to 800 ppm you'd get about 3Wm-2 opacity out of a total budget of 1360 Wm-2 that we get from the sun. Responsible for global warming? What sort of social justice wanker came up with that large lie?

author: alopam

text:
¬†@alopam¬† Don't know which country you belong to, but in India, we Geotag trees to ensure not only that physical planting actually took place but also to monitor the growth of the trees. Even if you plant a single tree, you can Geotag it and upload it to the Government website. So those 250 Million trees are actually there on the ground. Not just on paper.
.
Don't know what logic you are applying regarding Monsoon and Solar, but in reality its actually the opposite. Here is a paper with DOI: 10.1038/s41467-020-18318-7
It explains how India has excess solar and wind power capacity in Monsoon season insomuch that it has to curtail output by around 25% in Wind and 26% in Solar in the country. 
.
Whatever forest India lost was around 5% of total forest land in India. This drop occurred over two decades. Today, around 21% of Indian land is under forests. India set a goal in 2015 Pairs Climate Deal to reforest 33% of total Indian land area by 2030. In India, the problem today is degradation of forest, not deforestation. Overall, India's forest area is growing. Problem is that unsustainable use of firewood is leading to thinning out of dense forests. One thing the government has done to stop this is to provide heavily subsidized LPG for cooking and the effort has borne fruit. 
.
Most of these efforts have occurred only recently, under the current government that has been in power since 2014 (an year before the Paris Climate Deal). So the data of the 2001-2015 period is not a good indicator of what is about to happen in the future. This has already been seen in the growth of Renewables in India, the effect of forest conservation efforts will be visible after some more time. The kind of issues you are pointing to are surface issues. The Indian Central Government already understands them and has proven beyond doubt that its commitment to fighting climate change is genuine. Its not looking at total forest land, its also looking at quality of forests and is therefore targeting a trees as a certain Gigaton of additional Carbon sink. Some bureaucratic inefficiencies and leakages remain, but these are rapidly being addressed at a policy level.
author: Death Parade

text:
‚Äã¬†@Death Parade¬† 1. The "study" you provided is actually an article, a collection of overly optimistic projections, based on models. We live in the era of Covid, where models used to impose lockdowns have missed their target by as much as 2500%. So excuse me for not being as optimistic as you are...
2. What bothers me most is that you took a model and a projection and presented it as real world data. It is not. You either didn;t read the "study", or you are misrepresenting the facts in order to mislead me (and others).
3. The article uses some tricks in order to achieve its goals. For example, it bunches up solar and wind.  Also, it talks about storage, whereas this other article
https://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/power/opinion-energy-storage-in-india-a-perspective/76022409
says India didn;t have the legal framework for storage just one year ago, let alone the storage facilities...
4. Solar is great, except it;s inefficient, panels need replacing on average every 20-30 years, and it also takes a lot of coal to produce PV panels. Solar doesn;t  run in the dark. And without storage, what you;re doing with wind and solar is put a lot of power into the grid that gets wasted away, while at the same time running full power on fossil fuel.
5. The "study" runs on the presumption that fossil-fuel can be dialed up or down. That doesn;t happen in reality, because it takes days to power back up a coal plant and because constantly dialing it up or down destroys it.
6. For all its overly optimistic tone, even the article you quoted acknowledges coal is the single largest contributor to energy production in India and is set to remain the main energy source in the future. With consumption projected to increase 3-4 times in the coming decades, that means more coal burned, more CO2 produced.
7. I;'m not going to comment on the rest, it looks like you copy/pasted things from an Indian government propaganda pamphlet.
8. To sum things up, India buns lots of coal and is going to burn even more in the future. Probably as much as you would need full grown trees growing all over India to compensate just a bit of it. India has done some great solar projects. Even those projects have massive carbon footprints. And the green energy they produce goes to waste for the most part. It all depends on storage, with existing storage options being either very ridiculous (like using solar energy to pump oil/gas) or very misleading (battery production is very polluting in itself).
P.S. Do not get me wrong. I think highly of India and I trust the Indian government to do good for the environment. More than I trust my own government to do so. I just think we shouldn;t fool ourselves.
author: alopam

text:
¬†@alopam¬† 1.) You're right. I mistakenly presented a study as actual data. I apologize for that. Lets go back to your original assertion: "all those GigaWatts of Solar are powerless in-front of Monsoon clouds". Well, here is a study from a rooftop power plant in an Engineering Institute that looked seasonal variations: DOI -  10.1016/j.solener.2016.02.013 
This time I made sure its a study and not a simulation lol. From this study, we note tht while the average sunshine period drops quite a bit in Monsoon season, the variation in net monthly yield of power from the solar plant varies less. Variation is there no doubt, but not enough to be a deal-breaker. Moreover, as you said, battery storage policy has been released by Government of India, so its only a matter of time before solar storage starts widespread roll-out. India's 2030 target is for 60% of its installed capacity to be non-fossil fuels so that 40% of its electricity generation can be from non-fossil fuels. Clearly, Indian stakeholders are well aware of the impact of monsoon (and other seasonal variations) on Solar plants.
.
2.) You first insinuated that the 250 Million tree drive in India might be fake and I responded with how newly planted trees are geotagged to prevent fraud and cooked up numbers. And your response is that "I just copied government propaganda"? You tell me if this is a logical argument? Why are you so hell bent on being skeptical?
.
3.) I never disputed the fact that India would still need Coal power plants. Indian government had vociferously defended its historic right to Coal powered plants that provide the base load in the Paris Climate Deal. India's 2030 target as stated by India in 2015 Paris Deal is 40% of total electricity generation from non-fossil fuel sources. Fact remains that India is the only G20 country to have pledged enough to ensure a <2 degree rise in Global Temperatures. All other G20 nations have failed to pledge enough for a <2 degree rise. 
Source: climateactiontracker . org 
.
Yeah, I know, its just  pledge. Well, so far, India is working hard to achieve that pledge. The only risk is if India goes forward with construction of more Coal power plants as per the government's stated intentions of building 90GW of more Coal Power Plants. That said, its apparent that Indian Government is not trying to be opaque about its fight against Climate Change. It is making a genuine effort at balancing India's economic growth with reducing Carbon Emissions intensity.
author: Death Parade

text:
¬†@Death Parade¬† When I said about gov't propaganda I meant the last part, where your discourse sounded a lot like the "praise the almighty leader" speeches from the hay day of communist regimes.
Sorry for being skeptical. You obviously come from a very optimistic, pro-government background, whereas I operate on the presumption that governments (even more so today) aren't trustworthy. We are worlds apart, not just geographically :)
A pledge is just a pledge and if we look behind the curtains, we may discover a pledge is just a trick. With things being what they are, what I'm afraid will happen is we'll end up burning more coal for more power, while at the same time producing excess solar and wind that just goes to waste. Of course, if we produce as much green energy as fossil-fuel derived energy, we can claim we cut down our emissions by 50%. When in reality we raised our emissions and created a smoke screen for it. There's a term for that. I won;t use it, for fear I might get censored. It starts with "green" and end with "-ing" :)
The way I see it, the best solution would be to use solar and wind locally. The wind stops - you send the workers home or wait for it to pick back up. As long as it all pours down to the grid, and the certificates, we're just fooling ourselves. We can claim like Amazon or Google that we're 100% green when in fact you're still feeding off the gas and coal in the grid (plus you're operating a fleet of tens of thousand of diesel trucks lol).

text:
You have been severely misinformed on this topic, and I strongly encourage you to look at reliable science sources instead of anti-science propaganda. Some examples:
1) CO2 is a pollutant, a well-known greenhousegas. We have CO and CO2 detectors in our homes, because if those levels get too high, we die.
2) plants need more than just CO2 to grow, and having excessively high CO2 levels doesn't help plants. On top of that, plants "breathe", meaning they excrete CO2 back into the atmosphere as well. Furthermore, only some plants benefit from slightly higher CO2 levels (as in, in a greenhouse, under specific parameters, taken care of to make sure they get the right nutrients, sunlight, water intake, etc).
3) we're not plants.
4) we see a significant impact in CO2 and global warming. We came from about 0.02% and are up to 0.04%. While this may seem small, there are plenty of examples that can be given where such a difference can mean life or death. Just look at the food industry, for example.
5) the Sun's changing activity has caused a negative effect on average global temperatures, meaning if it were the Sun, the Earth would be slightly cooling, not heating up.
6) changes in the Earth's orbit occur over thousands of years, not in the span of 2 centuries.
7) there is no natural cycle or other natural event which can explain this rapid increase in average global temperatures.
8) we know without a shadow of a doubt that global warming is real, that it is entirely caused by our pollution (specifically ghgs) and that we'll be majorly screwed if we don't fix it.

So once more, PLEASE get a proper education in the matter before repeating anti-science propaganda.

text:
¬†@John Mac¬† CO2 is a poisonous gas too. That's why we also have CO2 detectors. There also the risk that CO2 fills up a room, while N2 almost always remains stable.

Yes, before humans, CO2 and temperatures were fairly stable and only changed based on natural cycles and phenomena. That's how we know with absolute certainty that this is not a natural event. We also know the Sun is fairly stable too. It has 11-year cycles and you usually see this in temperatures. Slightly hotter, slightly cooler. However, what we're seeing is a continuous rise in average global temperatures, despite the solar cycle and other natural effects.

Yes, methane is much worse, but also more fleeting. The biggest problem right now is CO2, but if we can reduce methane emissions at the same time, this is highly encouraged.

Finally, you should refrain from guessing. You suck at it.

text:
¬†@John Mac¬† more bullshit, as per usual. Typical for your kind. No knowledge about anything, but loving putting up a big mouth.

"without CO2 production, we'd go back to starving in caves" -> that's just utter and total bullshit and you know it. The Industrial Revolution didn't start until 1750, at which time civilisation was already pretty advanced and we had already achieved a great deal. So to say we'd go back to living in caves, makes zero sense, especially considering the fact that we have better sources now.

"no source of energy will reduce the effect humans have on this planet" -> again a completely false statement. Using resource efficient methods, we can significantly reduce our impact. Solar, wind, hydro, geothermal, etc. all have a far smaller impact on nature than fossil fuels do. On top of that, a lot of it can be recycled, meaning a far smaller footprint on top of that, and significantly reduced emissions. As we keep developping new technologies, we can further improve upon what we have, ever moving forward to a smaller impact on nature.

What do I do? Firstly, I informed myself properly and know that if my government produces a lot of renewable energy, this means that the electricity I consume has a far smaller footprint than if my country were to fully rely on fossil fuels. This has a massive impact, far greater than any one person can achieve. Even if I had a net zero impact, it wouldn't matter without this one factor. That being said, I don't own a car, use public transport if needed, have a healthy, balanced diet, recycle, etc. Normal stuff, but a big enough impact on reducing emissions.

So congratulations for once again proving your own statement that stupidity cannot be fixed.

text:
¬†@asdfgh78100¬† yeah, that's just simply not true. It's pure American propaganda with no basis in reality. America is historically the biggest pollutor in the world, and even today it's the number two. Under Obama, who was fully behind the Paris Climate Accords, some progress was made, but Trump was clearly against all that and made things worse again. No idea what Biden is going to do yet.

That being said, if we look at the data between 2000-2014, there were 21 countries in the world that both reduced their carbon emissions AND had economic growth. Out of those 21, the US ranked 18th at a 6% reduction. Number 1 was Denmark with 30% reduction. Now, granted, that data is a bit old now, but does set a good example against the American narrative that they're somehow not responsible for anything.

If we look at China, we see that they're by far the biggest producer of renewable energy, that they have the biggest growth in total amount of renewable energy produced, AND that they produce the most renewable energy sources (solar panels) which are sold worldwide. So while China is currently the biggest pollutor, they are clearly doing something about it, now having about 25% of their total energy production coming from renewables. Meanwhile, America is further and further lagging behind. Last info I saw put America at 14,7% renewables.

Congo and Venezuela are non-issues because their rainforests compensate for their small industries.

So once more, the claim that America is the biggest "good boy" in the world on this topic, is FALSE. Dozens of countries already rely on more than 50% renewable energy, and a few are already at 100%, like Iceland. America, arguably the biggest economy in the world, definitely has the assets to do what needs to be done, but does not have the political courage nor moral decency to do so. America doesn't give a fuck about anyone, not even America. And that's why you lag behind on everything. It's why the American Empire is falling.

author: Asedigive

text:
¬†@Asedigive¬† you've been severely misinformed by the typical anti-science propaganda. I always see the same arguments over and over. Lets go over them:

1) "1930s were hotter" -> the 30s were unusually hot, but ONLY IN AMERICA. The rest of the world was not effected. Local variations exist, but we're talking about GLOBAL warming, not local. On a global scale, the 1930s were a lot cooler than today.

2) we are currently living in the hottest period in 23 million years. The Medieval Warm Period, Roman Warm Period, Minoan Warm Period, whatever, they were all a lot cooler than today, and spread over centuries, not decades.

3) even within my lifetime, I've clearly seen global warming in action. Winters used to be cold and snowy, and summers would be exceptional if we had a few days in the 30s, but now winters rarely have snow or freezing temperatures, and summers are close to or at 40¬∞C. We also see more storms, droughts, floods, etc. as a result of global warming. Furthermore, this isn't about any local events, but a global problem. You can look outside your window in winter and think "hmm, it's cold, so global warming must be fake", but if you use your brain and think for a minute and realise it's not about your local area, but the world, you'll see this shit is real.

Seriously, stop following the anti-science propaganda. All those arguments have been thoroughly debunked decades ago. So tired to see you guys use the same bullshit over and over again. Get an education, mate.

text:
¬†@Roy Langston¬† you are grossly misinformed about this topic, which is evident by the fact that you rely on completely unreliable data, such as "I looked outside in winter, and it snowed, therefore it's fake". No, manmade global warming is absolutely real, and CO2 is a well-known, well-proven GHG.

Firstly, solar activity. Solar activity has been down for the last 2 decades. Based on this, we should be seeing a cooling effect. Instead, we get a rapid heating effect. So it's not the Sun.

Secondly, "CO2 is plant food" is so simplistic, it's just wrong. Plants can convert CO2 to O2, which is awesome, but at night they "exhale" CO2, and they release a lot of it at death as well. Furthermore, only some plants benefit from slightly higher CO2 levels, on the condition that they also get the right amount of sunlight, water, nutrients, etc. AKA in a controlled greenhouse setting, not in the real world. Also note, we're not plants.

Thirdly, the physical events you deny, are literally happening in front of us. The arctic ice is melting at record rates, having lost most of its mass already. Islands have already disappeared or are at risk of disappearing. The cold fronts America has experienced recently, are a result of global warming, as the arctic jet stream is destabilised and thus the polar vortex lashes out south. Growing seasons have become less stable as we get more volatile temperatures. We get more heat waves, destroying crops. Droughts, floods, storms, etc. When we look outside, beyond the length of our noses, or better yet: GO outside, we discover that manmade global warming is a reality. We used to have winters with snow. Summers used to be mild and only occassionally hit the 30s. It used to be a temperate zone. AGW is real, buddy. Hate to say it, but your anti-science propaganda is fooling you.

Fourthly, the Medieval Warm Period was a natural event over centuries, which only hit the northern hemisphere, and was far less of a problem than the current global warming crisis. We're now beyond that point, and it's not just local, it's global. We're at the hottest point in 23 million years.

Fifthly, while it's true that temperature has an effect on CO2, CO2 also has an equal effect on temperatures. Which happens to be one of the tipping points. If we spew out too much CO2, which is drawing closer by the minute, we'll come to a point where it's a perpetual cycle of high CO2 increasing temperature, and high temperatures increasing CO2. Thus heading towards Venus.

Please, Roy, learn about what the fuck you're talking about, because all you're doing is spewing long-debunked anti-science propaganda. Literally go to any science website to see you're wrong.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_weather_records#Temperature

Secondly, if this were just a natural evolution, the temperature increase would've stopped decades ago, yet contrary to any and all natural phenomena and cycles, it keeps on rising. There simply is no natural explanation for this. This should not be happening, based on all natural factors. The ONLY reason why the average global temperatures keep rising, is because of human pollution. This has been thoroughly proven through science, and is beyond doubt. No sane person in the world doubts this. Let me repeat that: no SANE person doubts it.

The scientists, which you call "charlatans" out of jealousy and complete and utter ineptitude, are absolutely right. The icecaps have been melting, sea levels have been rising, weather events have been more extreme, average global temperatures have been going up, plant and animal species have been going extinct, etc. Everything they said has been coming true. There's only one liar here, and that's you, Roy.

INEVITABLY.  You also don't understand that the natural return to more normal Holocene temperatures looks exactly like warming caused by CO2, except that it isn't caused by CO2.  Your "contrary to all known natural phenomena and cycles" claim is just a bald falsehood.  Etc., etc.

author: Roy Langston

text:
¬†@Roy Langston¬† I'll go grab you a napkin for all that mindless drivel you're spewing.

Lets destroy your "but we came from a cold period" bullshit yet again: if your argument were true, then coming out of a cold period would mean we'd go back to temperature levels we had prior to that cold period, right? So if we take 0¬∞ as the standard temperature pre-Little Ice Age, and the coldest point during the Little Ice Age was -1¬∞ standard temperature, then coming out of the Little Ice Age should get us all the way back to 0¬∞, aka the standard temperature as before the Little Ice Age. That's what would happen if you were right. And it did happen...and then temperatures kept rising...And kept rising...and kept rising...and now we're already 1,15¬∞ above pre-Little Ice Age temperatures and rising, and rising, and we'll be hitting +1,5¬∞ pretty soon. In fact, it hasn't been this hot in 23 MILLION years...so clearly this is NOT part of any natural cycle, or simply coming out of a slightly colder period. This is far beyond that. This is an abnormal, unnatural, very rapid increase in temperatures that cannot be explained through natural means. The only variable that has changed in that time, is the human factor. Humans destroyed more of nature, and pollute a hell of a lot more. We also know for a fact CO2 is a greenhouse gas which adds to the rise of global temperatures, and the analysis of carbon in the air confirms it's carbon emitted by humans, not nature. So EVERYTHING points to this not being natural, but caused by humans. Your argument stopped being true around the 1950s. Congratulations, you're only 70 years behind.

Anyone looking out their window, or better yet, looking at the world in general (because looking out the window is extremely local), can absolutely, 100% confirm I'm right and you're batshit crazy.

- icecaps are only a third of what they used to be. Clear proof you're wrong.
- heat records are being broken left, right, and center, and are far beyond what nature would have it at. Clear proof you're wrong.
- sea levels have risen, sinking several islands, flooding coastlines, and displacing people. Clear proof you're wrong.
- fauna and flora are going extinct at a very fast pace due to these rapid changes. Clear proof you're wrong.
- increase in extreme weather events, such as droughts, floods, forest fires, heavy hail storms, stronger hurricanes, etc. All clear proof you're wrong.
The list goes on and on.

So, here's a challenge to you: put your money where your mouth is and PROVE your position, instead of simply saying "nu'uh". If your next comment does not contain any proof for your claims, I'll consider it your admittion of defeat.

text:
¬†@Jehan Desains¬† You are not educable on this topic, but I will try to educate anyone else who might be reading.  You wrote:

That is a fact, not bull$#!+, so you are just lying.  You are liar.  Stop lying, liar.

We have not even reached the temperatures of the Medieval Warm Period, let alone the Holocene Optimum, as proved, repeat, PROVED by the fact that melting glaciers are revealing artifacts, villages, etc. from those periods.  It MUST HAVE BEEN WARMER THEN for those things to get there in the first place.  Liar.

No, that's just another lie from you, liar. It was unambiguously warmer in the Holocene Optimum just 6-10Kya.  It was also unambiguously warmer during the previous (Eemian) interglacial ~100Kya, and in the first half of the Pliocene, 3-5Mya:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geologic_temperature_record#/media/File:All_palaeotemps.svg

"so clearly this is NOT part of any natural cycle, or simply coming out of a slightly colder period."

Lie, as proved above.

Lie, as proved above.

"This is an abnormal, unnatural, very rapid increase in temperatures that cannot be explained through natural means."

Lie, as proved above: it HAS HAPPENED NATURALLY BEFORE, and therefore INDISPUTABLY CAN be explained through natural means now.  You are just LYING.

"The only variable that has changed in that time, is the human factor."

No, that is just another lie from you.  Many climate variables change all the time, including the positions of the continents, the earth's orbit, ocean currents, the sun, etc.  You are simply lying.  You are a LIAR.

"Humans destroyed more of nature, and pollute a hell of a lot more. We also know for a fact CO2 is a greenhouse gas which adds to the rise of global temperatures, and the analysis of carbon in the air confirms it's carbon emitted by humans, not nature."

Irrelevant.  None of that argues IN ANY WAY that post-Little-Ice-Age warming CANNOT have been caused by anything but CO2.

"- icecaps are only a third of what they used to be. Clear proof you're wrong."

You are lying.  The fact that ice caps got bigger during the coldest 500-year period in the past 10,000 years is in no way even evidence that I am wrong, let alone proof.

"- heat records are being broken left, right, and center, and are far beyond what nature would have it at. Clear proof you're wrong."

You are just lying again, as already proved.  We should EXPECT heat records to be broken when the earth has naturally returned to more normal Holocene temperatures following the coldest 500-year period in the last 10,000 years.  It is simply an artifact of natural variability.  Liar.

"- sea levels have risen, sinking several islands, flooding coastlines, and displacing people. Clear proof you're wrong."

Another bald lie from you.  All that proves is that temperatures have risen naturally since the coldest 500-year period in the last 10,000 years.  LIAR.

author: Roy Langston

text:
¬†@Roy Langston¬† I grow tired of your childish behaviour and your constant lying and bullshittery. You keep proving your utter and complete lack of knowledge and understanding of this topic. Seriously, go get a basic education.

1) the Medieval Warm Period was a LOCAL event, not a global one. This is an extremely important factor which you conveniently omit from your propaganda narrative. This means that in Greenland specifically, the place you're talking about regarding the archaeological finds, it was relatively hot compared to the global average and the average over time. This local warm period lasted for centuries, allowing the Vikings to settle there during the summer months. After the MWP, we saw centuries of building up ice, including during the Little Ice Age, all of which has since melted in a matter of decades (not centuries), and this very rapid warming is not just in Greenland, but is happening all over the world. Lets give some household analogies, in the hopes your feeble mind might understand. The MWP is like having a steak in the fridge, nice and cool, then putting it on the counter for a day to say "look, it's room temperature!". The current warming is like having that same steak put back into a freezer for several hours until it's nice and frozen, then putting it in a microwave for 10 minutes to find out that it's getting close to being cooked. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temperature_record_of_the_last_2,000_years#/media/File:2000+_year_global_temperature_including_Medieval_Warm_Period_and_Little_Ice_Age_-_Ed_Hawkins.svg -> here you see a nice, scientifically accurate representation of average global temperatures, including the MWP, LIA, and current warm period.

As per the Holocene Climate Optimum, this too was colder than today, and there's strong evidence suggesting it was not a global event either. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Holocene_Temperature_Variations.png -> As you can see on this graph, the hottest point of the HCO still falls far below today's temperatures (2016 being marked to the right of the graph). The northern hemisphere was warmer, but the tropics and southern hemisphere were cooler, which has a lot to do with landmasses I'd say. So once more, you've been completely proven wrong due to your ineptitude and lack of understanding of this topic.

The Eemian was a 15.000-year long period, reaching temperatures close to ours today, which we have surpassed already. Think about that for a while: nature needed thousands of years during a warm period to reach temperatures we reached in a span of decades due to human pollution. So seriously, take a good look in the mirror when calling someone a liar.

2)  here's a nice little graph showing natural vs human influence on our current climate: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Global_Temperature_And_Forces.svg -> as you can clearly see, this is NOT NATURAL. While nature COULD achieve temperatures similar to or higher than today's temperatures, and has done so in the past, it either does so over a prelonged period of time (centuries, millenia), or are a result of some big event, like an asteroid, supervolcanic eruption, etc. None of that is the case in the current warming period, which is entirely, 100% caused by human pollution. Based on natural factors alone, Earth should be cooling by 1¬∞C, not continue to rise. This also conclusively debunks your "Little Ice Age" tantrum for the umpteenth time. Let me spell it out for you again: if this were natural, temperatures would've stabilised 1¬∞C ago. The fact that it continues to rise at record pace, proves unequivocally that it's not natural and not due to the end of the Little Ice Age.

3) we are looking beyond just outside our window, and we know with absolute certainty, beyond any shadow of a doubt, regardless of all the lies you spew, that things are NOT normal. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_impacts_of_climate_change#Cryosphere -> more proof of rapid melting of ice. As shown in point 1, the natural Holocene temperatures are 1¬∞C lower than they are today, proving beyond any shadow of a doubt that this is far from natural, but in fact entirely caused by humans.

4) habitat loss is a result of rapid climate change, as droughts, floods, and unsuitable temperatures and extremes make areas ill suited for certain lifeforms. There have been far more severe weather events than ever before. Just look at forest fires, for example.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_change_and_ecosystems
The reduction in death toll has everything to do with modern society vs old society. Better building materials, faster response teams and medical help, international cooperation, etc.

There you have it, every single point you tried to make, failed miserably. You're embarassing yourself here, and calling me a liar every single sentence only makes you look even worse, especially after this very thorough beating.

Here's a list of the most common anti-science arguments on global warming. Please take a look at it first, before trying and humiliatingly failing to argue it against me: https://skepticalscience.com/argument.php

Here are the ones you tried:

Pack your bags, kid, you lost.

text:
¬†@Jehan Desains¬†  Wow, you got pretty exercised about this, ma'am. 
Just pointing out that climate change is constant. You can't stop climate change any more than you can stop time.
author: Carnak The Magnificent

text:
¬†@Carnak The Magnificent¬† "pretty excercised, ma'am" -> you're not used to a lot, are you, kid?

"climate change is constant, can't stop it"
-> this sounds like "forest fires are natural, never has there ever been any instance in all of history across the entire world of a human being responsible for a forest fire". It is extremely ignorant about reality and what the fuck is going on right in front of you.

Like I said, we're spewing gargantuan amounts of CO2 in the air, a known greenhouse gas. Average global temperatures have risen 1,15¬∞C in merely a century, and we know with absolute certainty that this is NOT natural. Nature is not behind this, WE ARE. And if we can cause a problem, we can fix it too.

You're just a typical ignoramus, uneducated and unwilling to get your head out of your ass to see reality and take responsibility for your actions.
author: Jehan Desains

text:
¬†@Jehan Desains¬†  I merely pointed out a fact, and you want to extrapolate into a whole bunch of presumptions. There is obviously an impact of Earth's natural climate cycles on whatever temperature changes we measure. 
Some people I respect believe that humans are contributing to a temperature increase on the planet. I'll accept that - within the context that whatever temperature cycles occur the climate would never be stagnant. 
Then comes the decisions about how we may respond. History demonstrates that as nations develop, citizens' expectations for a cleaner environment increase. That happens when people are free. The former Soviet Union was a climate disaster. China is likewise now. 
As US policy decisions, I favor continued expansion of natural gas use, which has improved the US' carbon emissions, and expansion of nuclear power.
As a world policy action which may seem unrelated, we should invest in providing clean water to poor nations. That will help them develop. Adaptation is our greatest asset.
Not that your demeanor merits such a reply as this.
author: Carnak The Magnificent

text:
¬†@Carnak The Magnificent¬† that's just it, you WEREN'T pointing out a fact. You made an argument implying humans are not responsible for the current rapid global warming event, even though all evidence proves we are.

All natural factors would see average global temperatures drop, not increase. This is not nature's doing.

China is actually doing quite well, having tripled their renewable energy production in the last 10 years, which increased its share from 17,66% to 26,73%. We should take an example of that, instead of refusing to take responsability. The only reason China uses so much fossil fuel, is because they're having an industrial revolution and are uplifting their gigantic population to western standards of living. Meanwhile, the US sits at 18,19% and the EU reached 19,7% in 2020.

Natural gas and nuclear don't fix the problem, they just create more. Nuclear especially, with the loads of problems they present. Going renewable is the only way, and both the US and EU need to up the ante to get there ASAP.

We can't adapt to the world ending. We only have one planet to live on. We need to change our ways so that this planet remains habitable for us.
author: Jehan Desains

text:
¬†@Jehan Desains¬† "You made an argument implying humans are not responsible for the current rapid global warming event." Incorrect, once again. You interpret it that way.  I pointed out the obvious fact that climate change occurs independent from human activity which is an observable fact (which you admit by stating the "current global warming event." It's current, but it's occurred before human activity could play any role.)

As we saw with COVID, there is no way to trust what the CCP self-reports. That you would see China's leaders as credible undermines your own credibility.

Yes we can and will adapt. Humans thrive in warmer weather.
author: Carnak The Magnificent

text:
¬†@Carnak The Magnificent¬† and once again, you're lying your ass off. Your very first comment was extremely clear in your intentions to deny human involvement in the current global warming crisis. It's one of the most common arguments made by science-deniers on this topic.

Human activity has played a role as soon as humans have played a role. And right now, humans are the one and only reason why this global warming crisis is happening in the first place. No humans, no global warming crisis.

We're not talking about the CCP, we're talking about objective, observable, scientific data. And if you deny Chinese info because they're unreliable, then we should deny US info because they've proven unreliable too often themselves.

Humans don't thrive in warmer weather. Look for the wet bulb effect. That's the point at which warm weather is deadly to us, which is already starting to happen in places like India. The warmest places are sparsely populated, such as the Sahara desert, or Saudi desert, or Ghobi desert. Furthermore, the fact that you reduce this existential crisis to "warmer weather" proves your complete and total ignorance about this topic. This isn't about slightly warmer weather, this is about increased droughts, increased floods, increased heat waves, stronger storms, bigger temperature fluctuations, rising sea levels, chain reactions starting which could tip us over the point of no return. The end of human existence is what awaits us if we don't fix this. And that's no exaggeration, that's reality.
author: Jehan Desains

text:
¬†@Jehan Desains¬† Wow. The Earth (and CCP) are so fortunate to have you on their side.
If you read back, you'll see that I actually that I conceded human contribution to current warming, yet you relate that as my intentions are "to deny any human involvement in the current warming" (crisis!) You use the word "warming" and it's a crisis. I use the word "warmer" and it's ignorance.
BTW, when you continually assume another person's supposed ignorance without actually knowing anything about them - that's called "a tell." 
And yes, humans do thrive when there are longer growing seasons, and less time constrained indoors during colder months sharing influenza and disease. 
You may have done a great deal of reading / study, but that does not necessarily mean you have come to correct conclusions, let alone that your conclusions supersede the conclusions of others, who may also have educations and favor alternative approaches (and that really bothers you, huh?)
author: Carnak The Magnificent

text:
¬†@Carnak The Magnificent¬† well, lets have an objective look at it, shall we? Every scientist and organisation in the entire world agrees manmade global warming is real, has already started the next mass extinction event, and will only get far worse if we don't fix it soon. The end of humanity is a reality of this crisis. Everyone also agrees we'll see more droughts, floods, heat waves, heavy storms, forest fires, migration, sea levels rising, disruptance of natural flows (sea and air), etc. all of which are terrible for life.

A real life example of how your "longer growing seasons" have already backfired: we used to live in a temperate zone. With a hotter, dryer climate, grapes grow better for wine production. However, the heat waves caused most of the grapes to shrivel up and dry out, causing a failed harvest. Droughts, floods, (hail)storms, these have all caused crops to fail as well, and are all more prevalent due to manmade global warming.

I see your kind all the time, in whatever scientific topic. You don't listen to the facts. You hear "warmer" and think "oh, sweet, we'll have nice, relaxing summer temperatures all year long with no negative consequences at all", but in reality we're in a mass extinction event. So this IS a crisis, and the scientific community has been pointing it out for decades.

How do we fix this? Partially by significantly reducing our carbon emissions. How do we do that the best way? Renewables. Why not nuclear? Because of the earlier mentioned problems of nuclear waste, lack of resources, proliferation, lack of safe locations, etc.

And honestly, whenever someone on the internet tries to bring up any potential credentials, real or made-up, I just ignore it. Why? Because if their education really made a difference, you'd see this in their conversations. A child who says Evolution is true, because they read it in a science magazine, has a better education than a Master of Biology who says Evolution is false due to him being a creationist. If that makes sense to you.

So, solutions? Renewables all the way, ASAP.
author: Jehan Desains

text:
¬†@Jehan Desains¬† So, if someone doesn‚Äôt agree with your views, then they are ignorant. However, if it turned out that someone were in fact educated, and did not agree with you, you would simply disregard what they have to say.  Good job insulating yourself from any conflicting insights.

Where crops grow may shift, but humans adapted, and yes, thrived, when their civilizations were far less capable than now.

No, not ‚ÄúEvery scientist and organisation in the entire world agrees (that) manmade global warming‚Ä¶ has already started the next mass extinction event, and will only get far worse if we don't fix it soon.‚Äù And certainly, you have some nasty things to say about Bjorn Lomborg, but he is just one. So, are you under-informed or are you trying to mislead? 

The UN Climate Panel report of 2014 stated that the total impact of Global Warming by 2070 would be the equivalent of each person losing 0.02 to 2% of our wealth ‚Äì over more than 50 years. The same panel also stated that average personal wealth should increase by 350% by that time. The impact of warming, then would suppress the average personal wealth to +336%. That‚Äôs certainly NOT an existential threat. And those are more informed scientists who don't agree that climate change is an existential threat.

Further, the UN also produced a report (2017?) which tackled the question: How do we prevent the anticipated 4 degree Celsius and keep it to no more than 1.5 Celsius by 2030? That UN report stated that even if all nations, not just wealthy nations, attempted to meet this goal, it would be incredibly difficult, fantastically expensive, if not impossible.

If we CORRECTLY understand climate change as one problem among many, we will prioritize our responses to multiple problems.
author: Carnak The Magnificent

text:
¬†@Carnak The Magnificent¬† no, when someone blatantly ignores reality and any and all evidence clearly proving them wrong, and refuse to educate themselves, then they're ignorant. As is the case with you. If someone WERE educated, but still blatantly ignores reality and any and all evidence clearly proving them wrong, then they're just liars. It's really not that hard to understand, IF you don't go out of your way to refuse to understand it, as you do.

"where crops grow may shift" -> in an ever expanding population, we need more crops and more stability in crop production. This is the OPPOSITE of what's happening due to manmade global warming. We get less suitable land and less stability in production, with more people. This means food shortages, which means famines, which means death. A very simple fact.

"humans adapted and even thrived" -> those few who survived managed to adapt to slowly changing climates and had long, stable periods. However, when there were sudden shifts, those civilisations quickly ended. The Akkadian Empire fell due to droughts. The Old Kingdom of Egypt fell due to droughts. Other areas in the world suffered as well during the 4.2kya event of droughts in some areas, and floods in others. With the Akkadian Empire, their northern region was their breadbasket. Just a couple of years of droughts meant their crops failed, which meant famine and disease, mass migration, conflict, death, and easy pickings for other entities like nomadic tribes which were otherwise a lot weaker. The availability of food is essential to the survival of not only a nation, but life as a whole. We are in a transition period of our own creation. We were in a good spot, good food production, stable climate, etc. and we started fucking that up. Now the climate is heating up rapidly and crops are already failing because of it. Now, thanks to globalisation and technology, we can handle a lot more than the Akkadians could, but the problem remains the same. Due to manmade global warming, the global climate changes in such a way as to reduce food production. Desertification is a serious problem in a lot of areas, droughts, floods, heat waves, hail storms, etc. causing even more problems. Like I said, even in my own area, we've seen crops fail several times due to such events.

Yes, every scientist and organisation in the world agrees we created the next mass extinction event due to manmade global warming. This is not disputed. Bjorn Lomborg has a PhD in political science, not anything related to the climate. As such, he has frequently been called out for cherry-picking, downplaying, and misrepresenting data to come to false conclusions. Not a credible source when it comes to science. In fact, he's considered a non-scientist pushing opinion pieces rather than scientific evidence. So if your great example of people disagreeing with climate science is a non-scientist with no formal education related to the topic, who has been frequently called out for misrepresenting the data, then I'm definitely not impressed. Even if it were an ACTUAL scientist with ACTUAL knowledge of the topic, with an opinion deviating from the evidence, it wouldn't change anything. Is this seriously all you've got?

I've skimmed the IPCC report of 2014 and did not find what you claimed. Please refer me to the page in that report. Best case scenario for you, is you blatantly ignored everything else in the article which proves you wrong and you cherry-picked data which, in context, destroys your claims. Especially since the entire IPCC is in agreement that this IS an existential threat that needs global attention and action. And while everyone agrees it would be expensive to fix and would face its challenges, everyone also agrees that NOT fixing it would mean the end of us all.

Correctly understanding manmade global warming is clearly not an option for you, who deliberately ignores and denies any and all evidence of its reality.

text:
¬†@azchris1979¬† the issue of polar bears and smog are not the main issue in this video. 
If you think smog isn't bad, just look up the amount of people it kills worldwide.
The main issue is the amount of carbon dioxide humanity has dumped into the atmosphere. Increasing carbon dioxide has been scientifically demonstrated to cause climate change. This fact has been known since around 1880. 
Fortunately, renewable energy technology has made massive progress and with sufficient political will, the problem of climate change could be solved by 2050. 
I have been contributing to planting trees and protecting forests since 2010.
author: John Wedderburn

text:
¬†@John Wedderburn¬† 
Okay, you don't like what I talked about and insist we talk about what you want to talk about. Fine. Why would you assume I think smog isn't bad? What a strange thing to say. Yes, of course smog is bad. I have never met the "pro-smog" people myself. 
Yes, CO2 and climate are linked, but I can tell you have bought into some serious paranoia. Do you believe in the "runaway greenhouse effect?" Do you think Venus has an important lesson about CO2 for us? These are BS fear merchant talking points.
Nothing wrong with planting trees and such, but don't delude yourself into thinking it has even a .0000000000000001% effect on anything.
2 things to cure your anxiety:
1. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N6Hgt3sicQI&ab_channel=WorldStats We got plenty of trees. In the USA it is even increasing.
2. Yes Brazil is on a downward trend and I suppose could go through all of it in 180 years at this rate, but you should know that if the entire rain forest disappeared overnight...everything would be fine. It would be horrible for the ecosystem of course, but the planet will barely notice. Its far better to spend you time worrying about the things you can actually effect.
author: azchris1979

text:
¬†@azchris1979¬†  what are you talking about? 
I said if you think smog isn't bad, I didn't assume it. You ignored the "If" at the start of that sentence. 
Did I mention a runaway climate model or Venus? 
No I didn't. 
I stated that Carbon Dioxide levels are linked to climate change. Furthermore, I clearly stated that progress in renewable energy technology can solve the problem of climate change. So I have no idea where that idea that I'm paranoid or fearmongering comes from. 
I never said planting trees and protecting forests was a solution to climate change. I already stated that renewable energy sources was the solution to climate change. However, planting trees and protecting forests can help slow down climate change thus buying us time to transition over to renewable energy sources. 
From what I have read, there is potentially enough area of land, and even more if a majority of people became vegan, to plant a trillion extra trees. 
That's enough trees to extract approximately 5 to 50 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide out of the air every year.
Also, if you are skeptical of climate change, then why do you care if I plant trees and protect forests? 
I plant trees that also help lift people out of poverty. So, even if climate change turns out to have been a mistaken idea* then the local environment and people will still have benefited.

*I will never understand why people are so quick to assign malice and accuse people who accept the science of climate change as engaging in a hoax, or those who are skeptical of catastrophic anthropogenic climate change as being deniers. Never assign to malice that which can more easily be explained by ignorance.
author: John Wedderburn

Seems I was a bit over cautious with you. So if I was wrong about that, I have no problem with accepting that you seem to have a pretty rational take you are just a little over-eager to share.

text: Making the graph a sum total rather annual output is a mistake. CO2 emissions do not stay in the atmosphere indefinitely. CO2 emissions from fifty years ago are not having an impact today. Countries that produced more emissions in the past but have reduced their impact in recent years look worse while countries that produced little or no emissions before but are now the worst emission producers look better than they really are. No other stat video does it this way, they all show annual numbers, so viewers who are used to other stat videos will probably misunderstand what they are seeing and be confused. üëéüèªüëéüèªüëéüèª

text:
Early in life, I began wondering that since very little of a tree is left behind as solid residue when it‚Äôs burned, how is it that the bulk of a tree‚Äôs mass is vaporized?¬†
Behind that question lies an answer:
‚Ä™https://www.canr.msu.edu/news/where_do_trees_get_their_mass_from‚Ä¨

To begin with, half of the mass of wood is carbon that, when burned, combines with atmospheric oxygen and is released as carbon dioxide (CO2): a unit of carbon combines with two of oxygen. Since the mass of oxygen weighs more than three times as much as carbon, burning just two pounds of wood yields over eight pounds of CO2.
[1 pound carbon + 3.6 pounds oxygen + 3.6 pounds oxygen = 8.2 pounds of carbon dioxide]

Note: Trees, as they grow, re-absorb carbon dioxide from the air; but, with increasing deforestation, desertification, soil degradation, et al, CO2 levels in the biosphere are increasing (especially when you factor in the burning of stupendous amounts of previously sequestered carbon in the form of fossil fuels).

This strengthens the greenhouse effect and results in a steadily warming planet. And with each and every year being warmer than the years before, only the blissfully ignorant and the hopelessly naive can fail to see what the future holds.

‚Äòcarbon cycle global warming‚Äô

text: Eh, try again. This is based on "known" historical evidence. China is, by far, the one with the most CO2 emissions. What people fail to realize, is that plant life relies on CO2, and they give an O2 exchange. There is a balance between the two. When trees and brush are cut down and cleared away, instead of replanting, the balance will be disrupted. This is why it is so important to replant our forests that have burned or are over cut. To cut CO2 emissions down to near or to zero is impossible. It would be a disaster for our planet.

text: Not accurate. We didn‚Äôt start measuring Co2 until 1952 in Hawai‚Äôi. This is mostly propaganda. If you really want to know true data check the EPA, NASA and others. As a proportional measure of emissions of the global total, China and India combined are over 40% and increasing exponentially. Whereas the EU and the USA are 24% and dropping. Focused improvements on clean energy and reducing carbon based emissions through improved production is helping the EU and USA. But also, less industrial production is reducing emissions for the EU and USA. Whereas China and India are fast expanding industrial output and without strict regulation.

text: An American farmer was horrified when saw his crops covered in smoke from a forest fire.  He thought he was facing financial ruin. Broad leaf trees take in Co2 through their leaves and through the photo genetic process, separate the carbon from the oxygen.  The oxygen is expelled through the leaves and the carbon is gratefully received.  It is a scientific fact that there is a dearth of carbon in the world. text: It's not just about CO2 emmissions but about the heat energy released into the atmosphere from the burning of fuel. An electrically driven train may not emit CO2 into the atmosphere but electric engines get hot too. Where does that waste heat go to? The atmosphere. Much better than a diesel driven train. Hydrogen is a much cleaner fuel than fossil fuels but burning hydrogen also puts heat into the atmosphere. Much better for us all regarding CO2, SO2 and NO2's but there is still heat put into the atmosphere. The Global warming table is not about who has pumped the most CO2 into the atmosphere it's also about the heat energy thrust into the air. When the World and especially then environmentalist wake up and realise that it's not just CO2 and it's about the heat used when we use energy too then, and maybe only then, will the world wake up and do something useful. More and more efficient use of energy would be better. You can build all the wind turbines, solar energy farms, and tidal power units that you need. When you generate energy you create heat energy. You will not have solved the problem.

I don't see Bill Gates giving away all of his fortune to a random human on the other side of the globe, instead of his successors, just an example. If people who succeded others can't accept the responsiblity their "parents" (for the sake of the argument, to make it less scary, I'm comparing nations to a family here) gave them than that says more about the apathy and the inaction and passive ignorance of our generation than about some morally superior "forgiveness" preaching, and as you described well, people don't care, it shows, it's not about whether or not people are "guilty" (or, again, "responsible", which is the better term for this) that they are really worried about, it's about whether or not they are entitled to care or not, and when it's not affecting them, they can choose to not care, so no responsibility for them. Fair enough for their instant-pleasure-obsessed small minds and big egos but in the eyes of history the people of the future will know who's most responsible for what. And some were way more than others, logically. I don't think anybody would giive a pass for the wrongdoings of long gone and long changed ancient civilizations, in the distant future people will look back and won't feel ashamed if their millennia-distant relatives committed terrible mistakes, maybe that's the only way humans can admit a fuckup, centuries after it's been done. Hope one day we grow up on that front, it's about time.

author: pawelpap9

text:
¬†@pawelpap9¬† I have the discipline and the knowledge. The key word is system and the extension "ology" which means study of, science of & theory of... from the Greek root ŒªŒøŒ≥ŒπŒ± (logia) meaning to speak (of).

And for your information the Industrial Revolution began about 1760 and for most of the early years any ability to excavate and burn fossil fuels was limited by the fact it had to be done by hand. It wasn't until the mid 1800s that the process became mechanised and began to exponentially accelerate. It was no longer a cottage industry and they kept excellent records at that point, and as we began to massively extract and burn the fossil fuels that had lain underground for 370 million years, the earth's temperature began to rise.

Odd that!

At the rate we are burning fossil fuels we are creating¬†21.3 gigatonnes of carbon dioxide per year, accumulating and accelerating.¬†

That does not include the massive amount of burnt and destroyed trees and plant matter, nor the stupendous amount of methane produced by agriculture. We are already at the tipping point where methane lying frozen under the tundra is melting and¬†erupting¬† with even more methane deep in the ocean that will be released by rising sea temperatures.

Most dangerously the conditions no longer exist for the massive burial and fossilisation of the carbon that happened in a relatively short period during the Carbonaceous, which is why that period got its name.

...but as "a scientist myself" you would know that. 

...or not, ...apparently.

If you haven't noticed with all these time animated statistics there are abrupt changes when for example the Soviet Union breaks up and Russia becomes the remnant portion and the republics break loose to form their own barline. From Wikipedia "From 1867 it was a Polish-administered autonomous crownland¬†under¬†Cisleithanian¬†Austria-Hungary" so not a problem for gathering statistics.

Data is always difficult to model, but these examples are there to show relative volumes and the degree of the problem, which is obviously escalalting at a horrendous pace.

text:
¬†@Peter Breis¬† "Since the USA creates as much as the next three polluters combined (despite having less than 1/6th the population), and it is all relative, the exact figure with margin for error is pretty irrelevant." This may or may not be true. If you are going just by the graphs in this video, you cannot make that statement. You could say "The USA, from 1880 to date, has produced more greenhouse gasses than the next three combined but you can't correctly say (based on the graphs) that it is currently producing as much as the next three combined.
Oddly, if you look at annual figures, in most years the USA does indeed produce as much as the NEXT three combined (India, Russia, Japan), but the USA is no longer at the top. China produces more greenhouse gasses than the USA does and produces as much as the next five (USA, India, Russia, Japan, Germany). Btw, the USA, Canada and Germany (three of the top ten) are currently reducing their carbon footprints. Maybe not as quickly as others would like, but CO2 production is still going down.

Now, if you want to point the finger at the USA for causing most of the damage, fine, I won't argue with you. But if the USA reduced its carbon footprint to zero, you would still have a problem because the concentration of greenhouse gasses in the atmosphere would still be increasing.

text:
At the end it says that the data is supplied by CDIAC.  The Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center (CDIAC) was an organization within the United States Department of Energy that had the primary responsibility for providing the US government and research community with global warming data. The CDIAC's only job was to collect data related to climate change and greenhouse gas emissions.  CDIAC was only founded in 1982 and closed September 30, 2017.

The only reliable MEASURED data that it can have collected is thus between 1982 and 2017 and it can only have collected data in the USA as most of the other countries have their own centres or don't collect anything.  There is no evidence for any of these figures- none.

I  want to know where this data came from otherwise, as far as I am concerned it is propaganda.  For example, I went to China in 1989 and it was positively spewing masses and masses of smoke, fumes etc into the air, all the heating and cooking was also CO2 producing.  The air over the canals was so thick with pollutants,  it made your eyes water.

And I've also been to India, home to the kerosene light the wood stove and vehicles that once upon a time turned the air rust coloured.  And every home - a billion or so - had one.  This animation does not make sense, and I do not say this out of denial I say it out of doubt that any of this could have been collected.

author: redplague

text:
¬†@redplague¬† I'm glad you at least didn't mention that 97% of scientists statistic which is fudged and easily debunked. Well one of the causes is that rather large fireball 100 million miles from us. 

Seriously, solar activity, changes in the Earth's orbit and axial tilt, shifting ocean currents, other gases such as methane and water vapor, volcanic activity, cosmic rays, stratospheric circulation, reflectivity caused by level of forestation, population and land use policy...

It's also a fact that manmade CO2 is only about 3.5% of the total, greenhouse gases all combined are only 2% of our atmosphere. The largest greenhouse gases are methane and plain old water. Our current CO2 level is historically very low, at about 400 ppm; we've had ice ages with ten times higher concentrations of CO2. 

Finally, the "scientific" conclusions of groups like IOCC can't be trusted as they've been wrong SO MANY times before! I could give a huge list of predictions made by Al Gore and climate scientists that never came true. There are many climate scientists, some part of the IPCC, who have defected over the years. The original founder of Greenpeace has even left the organization.

The bottom line is that of course climate change is real. We should take common sense steps to find other sources of energy, even if it's only because the current ones are of limited supply. But the truth is at the moment, wind and solar cannot possibly produce enough energy to replace fossil fuels. MAYBE if you include nuclear energy we'd come close. So what I won't do is give in to the hysterics coming from the climate activists, how this is some sort of emergency that we'll all be dead in 20 years if we don't make drastic changes *right now and not even ask any questions on pain of being branded science deniers*. We hear we have 10 years to "turn things around," and I'm old enough to remember that we've been told this for at least 40 years, none of their dire predictions have come true, so groups like IPCC, between their failed predictions and fudged data have lost much of their credibility.
author: tomservo

text:
‚Äã¬†@tomservo¬† The 97% figure you've come up with is just not true.  In actual fact there a scientific consensus on the issue of climate change.  The Academies of Science from 80 countries plus many scientific organizations that study climate science. 
Consensus on Consensus - Cook et al. (2016) was a co-authored paper that settled the expert climate consensus question once and for all. The two key conclusions from the paper are:

1) Depending on exactly how you measure the expert consensus, it‚Äôs somewhere between 90% and 100% that agree humans are responsible for climate change, with most of the studies finding 97% consensus among publishing climate scientists.

2) The greater the climate expertise among those surveyed, the higher the consensus on human-caused global warming.

Solar activity - A number of independent measurements of solar activity indicate the sun has shown a slight cooling trend since 1960, over the same period that global temperatures have been warming. Over the last 35 years of global warming, sun and climate have been moving in opposite directions. An analysis of solar trends concluded that the sun has actually contributed a slight cooling influence in recent decades (Lockwood 2008).

Earth's orbit and tilt - Yes this affects climate however these orbital phases are in patterns of tens of thousands of years.  We are currently in a relatively cool orbital phase, whilst the Earth is getting warmer.

Ocean currents - are changing because of climate change affecting the ice caps, not the other way around.

Methane  - is a more potent greenhouse gas than CO2 but there is over 200 times more CO2 in the atmosphere. Eg - CO2 levels are 380 ppm while methane levels are 1.75ppm. Hence the amount of warming methane contributes is calculated at 28% of the warming CO2 contributes.

Water vapour - Water vapour is the dominant positive feedback in our climate system and amplifies any warming caused by changes in atmospheric CO2. This positive feedback is why climate is so sensitive to CO2 warming.

Volcanic activity - Volcanoes emit around 0.3 billion tonnes of CO2 per year. This is about 1% of human CO2 emissions which is around 29 billion tonnes per year.

Cosmic rays - There has been no correlation between cosmic rays and global temperatures over the last 30 years of global warming.  In fact, in recent years when cosmic rays should have been having their largest cooling effect on record, temperatures have been at their highest on record.

Stratospheric circulation - The effect from stratospheric water vapor contributes a fraction of the temperature change imposed from man-made greenhouse gases.

CO2 and methane were involved in most of the climate changes in Earth‚Äôs past. When they were reduced, the global climate became colder. When they were increased, the global climate became warmer. When CO2 levels jumped rapidly, the global warming that resulted was highly disruptive and sometimes caused mass extinctions. Humans today are emitting prodigious quantities of CO2, at a rate faster than even the most destructive climate changes in earth's past.  Therefore not an example I would use to try and brush human influence aside.

You could give a huge list of errors of the IPCC but you don't even give a short one so I'll try and guess what you were talking about (you may find there are some issues you didn't know about):-

Himalayan glaciers - They said they would disappear by 2035.  Obviously that's not going to happen but that was one paragraph of a 1000 page report.  However satellites and on-site measurements are observing that Himalayan glaciers are disappearing at an accelerating rate.  Man-made climate change deniers will often focus on isolated incorrect predictions from scientists but fail to acknowledge the huge amount of mistakes they make and the flawed science they use.  The moral of the story is stick to peer reviewed scientific literature as this report initially wasn't.  When it finally was the error was corrected and the rest of the huge report was left intact, something that deniers conveniently fail to mention.

Amazon rainforests -  The IPCC statement on Amazon rainforests was correct, and was incorrectly reported in some media.  The error was incorrect citation, failing to mention the peer-reviewed papers where the data came from. The peer-reviewed science prior to the 2007 IPCC report found that up to 40% of the Brazilian forest is vulnerable to drought. Subsequent field research has confirmed this assessment.

Incorrect temperature predictions - This came from a claim from by climate change denier Lord Monkton.  The IPCC surface temperature projections have been exceptionally accurate thus far.  Lord Monckton has taken a single equation from the IPCC, used it in an inappropriate manner, and then attributed his results to the IPCC.  He uses a method that is clearly intended to examine the long-term response of temperature to changes in carbon dioxide, and which is never used by the IPCC (nor should it be) to make predictions about current temperature trends. A slight change in Lord Monckton‚Äôs methodology as of July 2010 still does not make his method or attribution remotely appropriate.

Medieval warm period - The original global temperature schematic which appeared in the IPCC First Assessment Report and seemed to show the Medieval Warm Period hotter than present was based on the central England temperature record, and ended in the 1950s. It was only a schematic, and based on one isolated geographic location. Subsequent IPCC reports showed actual hemispheric temperature reconstructions. They did not "disappear" the MWP, they simply presented the best available data.

Dire predictions - Numerous papers have documented how IPCC predictions are more likely to underestimate the climate response.  The IPCC lead authors are experts in their field, instructed to fairly represent the full range of the up-to-date, peer-reviewed literature. Consequently, the IPCC reports tend to be cautious in their conclusions. Comparisons to the most recent data consistently finds that climate change is occurring more rapidly and intensely than indicated by IPCC predictions.

In the scientific community and media, IPCC's reports are broadly viewed as the most comprehensive and reliable assessments of climate change. In 2007, the IPCC was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.  So they are absolutely credible and don't cease to be because you say so.

Al Gore's film was "broadly accurate" according to an expert witness called when an attempt was made through the courts to prevent the film being shown in schools. While there are minor errors in 'An Inconvenient Truth', the main truths presented - evidence to show mankind is causing global warming and its various impacts is consistent with peer reviewed science.  It's worth pointing out that Al Gore is a politician, not a climate scientist.
author: redplague

text:
¬†@redplague¬† What SPECIFIC consensus did these agencies come to? That's important. Of course climate change is real, you don't need a study for that. As for the 97% consensus, here's how they arrived at that fudged number:

Definitions of consensus:
1. Unquantified: "We are causing some global warming." 

2. Standard (quantified): " Human activity is very likely causing some of the global warming (anthropogenic) - Less consensus since we're really not sure of the amount. But Cook et al. says they have 97% consensus on this "official" version.

3. Catastrophist: "Our influence is dangerous enough to justify a 'climate policy.'

Cook et al. 2013: "Scientific consensus is 97.1% that human activity is very likely causing most of the current anthropogenic global warming"
11,944 abstracts reviewed        100%
7,930 excluded for expressing no opinion    (66.4%)
3,896 marked as "agreeing we cause some warming" (32.6%) - this is Definition #1 (what we agree on).
64 marked as endorsing consensus as defined (0.5%)  (Definition #2)
But only 41 actually endorsed consensus #2 as defined (0.3%)  - this is the "very likely causing some..."
0 marked as catastrophic (Definition #3)

Remove the 7,930 from 11,944 and you get 4,014 papers expressing an opinion.
3,896 / 4014 = 97.1%
author: tomservo

text:
‚Äã¬†@tomservo¬† Cook et al was based on the abstracts of papers that took a position on climate change.  So if a paper didn't explicitly say "very likely" then it wouldn't be included in that section.  This is why so many papers were rejected for having no opinion.  A lot of these papers were concerned with methodology rather than summaries and also because so many climate scientists now accept that humans are causing global warming there would be no reason to explicitly state it given that the point of the papers was not clarify whether it was.  This is standard on any analysis of consensus.  The important results of this paper were:-

66.4% of abstracts expressed no position on AGW (anthropogenic global warming), 
32.6% endorsed AGW, 
0.7% rejected AGW and 
0.3% were uncertain about the cause of global warming. 
Among abstracts expressing a position on AGW, 97.1% endorsed the consensus position that humans are causing global warming.  So the figure is sound.

There was also phase 2 of the study which you omitted:-  Authors were invited to rate their own papers to take into account non definitive summaries:-  
A smaller percentage of self-rated papers expressed no position on AGW (35.5%). Among self-rated papers expressing a position on AGW, 97.2% endorsed the consensus.  
Also the paper found  that for both abstract ratings and authors' self-ratings, the percentage of endorsements among papers expressing a position on AGW marginally increased over time. The analysis indicates that the number of papers rejecting the consensus on AGW is a vanishingly small proportion of the published research.

If you want to argue the legitimacy of that figure from that one paper then that's fine but high figures of consensus have been backed up by subsequent studies:-

Oreskes 2004 and Peiser - A survey of all peer-reviewed abstracts on the subject 'global climate change' published between 1993 and 2003 shows that not a single paper rejected the consensus position that global warming is man caused.  75% of the papers agreed with the consensus position while 25% made no comment either way (focused on methods or paleoclimate analysis).

Doran 2009 -  A survey of 3146 earth scientists asked the question "Do you think human activity is a significant contributing factor in changing mean global temperatures?". More than 90% of participants had Ph.D.s, and 7% had master‚Äôs degrees. Overall, 82% of the scientists answered yes. However, what are most interesting are responses compared to the level of expertise in climate science. Of scientists who were non-climatologists and didn't publish research, 77% answered yes. In contrast, 97.5% of climatologists who actively publish research on climate change responded yes.

Anderegg 2010 - An independent study that surveys all climate scientists who have publicly signed declarations supporting or rejecting the consensus. They find between 97% to 98% of climate experts support the consensus. Moreover, they examine the number of publications by each scientist as a measure of expertise in climate science. They find the average number of publications by unconvinced scientists (eg - skeptics) is around half the number by scientists convinced by the evidence. Not only is there a vast difference in the number of convinced versus unconvinced scientists, there is also a considerable gap in expertise between the two groups.
