author: redplague

text:
¬†@redplague¬† I think the take-home point here is that if we're going to talk about consensus, and the issue of climate change overall, we need to get very specific with definitions. The climate alarmists do a very good job of conflating issues. What exactly is this consensus? That the climate changes? That humans have something to do with it? Is it the level of human involvement? Does the consensus provide a timescale? Can they agree on the degree of change? And is some global warming even a bad thing? There are so many shades of gray, and the question, "Is man-made climate change real" is a completely meaningless question, it's actually several dozen questions with all sorts of nuance. I'd also like to see one of the alarmists answer the question: What EXACTLY is the ideal global temperature and CO2 level? What should we shoot for and how do we know (quantitatively) when the goal is reached? Those types of questions produce crickets. If we cannot answer those questions, or agree precisely what this consensus is, then the debate is over before it begins. The alarmists will throw around terms like "climate denier" to anyone who opposes them, without realizing what they're saying.  They know damn well that no one denies the existence of the climate, they use these terms to shut up any opposition and brand them as uneducated buffoons. They will NEVER be specific as to exactly what science has a consensus on, because the truth is it depends on the exact conclusion, and furthermore science is not perfect either. Scientists make mistakes too. Even furthermore, they know deep down that the problem can never be "solved" for if it is, they lose their cause. It's my observation that people complaining about various ills in society never seem interested in fixing those ills lest they lose them as campaign issues.

So the bottom line is that I have seen no proof, nor even consensus, that justifies the dramatic "solutions" we're seeing, such as Green New Deal*, no consensus on the more catastrophic positions of the climate alarmists, which have failed to come true over and over. I'm old enough to remember in the 70s and early 80s it was all about global cooling, then that turned out not to be true it turned to "global warming" and when that fizzled, the ultimate bet-hedger, "climate change" (as if their opponents are claiming that climate change is not real when everyone knows it's been changing on its own for 4 billion years).  Even the Cook Report fails to make the case that expert climatologists such as former VPs, TV personalities, former bartenders, lazy Socialist Senators, and emotionally-challenged high school girls are trying to make that we're somehow in the middle of some catastrophe.  I could give fact after fact, quote after quote from people like Marc Morano, Lord Monckton, and many climatologists who have left the global warming bandwagon (at great expense to their careers, I might add), and one make the counter that they're somehow "paid off by big oil" or "conservative shills", and I can equally point to the fact that most of the climate alarmists provide no proof and have no scientific credentials of their own. If one writes off the so-called "climate deniers" as conservative conspiracy theorists (as if we have some secret planet of our own that we fly home to at night so we don't have to live on the same planet as the alarmists), and yet accepts the pleas of a 16-year old Swedish girl and a bartender without any question, that shows this has become an entirely political issue. *BOTH sources, pro and against should be open to question and have to defend their stances, and yet only one of them is made to. We know science does not operate on consensus, it's in constant flux. Even something as basic as gravity has been turned on its head in just the last 100 years. It was once settled science that the Earth was at the center of the universe, that dark-skinned people were less intelligent (the "science" of phrenology), that there was nothing smaller than an atom, I could go on and on and on about the mistakes that science has made over the centuries; to say that ANYTHING is "settled science" is the most UN-scientific thing someone can do. So my objection is not so much to the assertion of man-made effect on the environment, that is a legitimate debate. My objection is to the people who demand that we accept THEIR hysterical theories, and that ANY questioning, any attempt to debate the issue is akin to the denial of the very existence of science itself. They come off as the used car dealer who seems just a little bit too anxious to sell you that car and hopes you don't look up its service history. The term "science denier" is an obvious crock (no one denies the existence of science or the climate) but it's intended to be politically divisive and shut down and censor anyone who doesn't agree with their radical solutions like the Green New Deal. Science does not operate that way. The whole point of this "science" which we're supposed to be against, is observation, data gathering and then debate on the meaning of the raw data. The eagerness by which the alarmists want to ram through their ideas, branding any opposition as some knuckle-dragging ignorant neanderthal takes away any credibility their side might otherwise have had.
author: tomservo

text:
¬†@tomservo¬† Well a scientific consensus is reached when scientists stop arguing.  In terms of climate change nearly all have stopped arguing as the data I've provided you shows.  Man made climate change deniers put ridiculous demands on science that nobody should be arguing as your own refusal to accept this data shows.  Science is never 100% settled - science is about narrowing uncertainty. Different areas of science are understood with varying degrees of certainty. We have a high understanding of the warming effect of carbon dioxide. Poorly understood aspects of climate change do not change the fact that a great deal of climate science is well understood. 
I would agree though that climate scientists have done a poor job of communicating this to the general public.  In fact I would say deniers have done a better job of spreading conspiracies and bad science amongst the public.  I'm not sure exactly why this is but I have a couple of theories of my own:-
1.  Scientists, with a few notable exceptions, are not really concerned with how the public of media perceives them and just concentrate on their work.  Whereas deniers, the majority of which aren't climate scientists tend to understand and are better able to use the media in seeding doubt.
2.  Scientists will use facts, figures and graphs to illustrate their point.  I think a lot of the general public's eyes tend to glaze over at such things.  Deniers on the other hand will rely on rhetoric, hyperbole and cherry-picking to make their points very loudly.

In terms of what the consensus is on, well it's that humans are causing global warming.  Of course there is the question of how much.  One of the results of the Abstracts Survey dealt with this question.  This was a survey of abstracts like the other ones I told you about. A copy and paste of the results of this:-


*In our survey, among scientists who expressed a position on AGW in their abstract, 98.4% endorsed the consensus.  This is greater than 97% consensus of peer-reviewed papers because endorsement papers had more authors than rejection papers, on average.  Thus there is a 97.1% consensus in the peer-reviewed literature, and a 98.4% consensus amongst scientists researching climate change.  
We fully anticipate that some climate contrarians will respond by saying "we don't dispute that humans cause some global warming." First of all, there are a lot of people who do dispute that there is a consensus that humans cause any global warming. Our paper shows that their position is not supported in the scientific literature.

Second, we did look for papers that quantify the human contribution to global warming, and most are not that specific. However, as noted above, if a paper minimized the human contribution, we classified that as a rejection. For example, if a paper were to say "the sun caused most of the global warming over the past century," that would be included in the less than 3% of papers in the rejection categories.

Many studies simply defer to the expert summary of climate science research put together by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), which states that most of the global warming since the mid-20th century has been caused by humans. According to recent research, that statement is actually too conservative.

Of the papers that specifically examine the human and natural causes of global warming, virtually all conclude that humans are the dominant cause over the past 50 to 100 years.*

If you still don't accept this consensus from all the data I've given you then I can't really think of anything else to convince you as you're basically just sticking your finger in your ears and yelling "la, la, la".

I'm all for making the qualifications of what is considered a consensus more robust.  I mean why should barely qualified, if at all, people publish climate science papers and be considered in those figures.  I don't take my medical advice from a mechanic.  Let's just take into account the qualified climate scientists.  Of course the bad news for people like yourselves is that it makes your job harder as it's the qualified climate scientists that are overwhelmingly part of the consensus making it even more robust.

Ultimately if deniers wish to prove the vast majority of climate scientists wrong then they have to provide theories as to why the world is getting warmer that can be observed, proved and have repeatable results.  So far they have failed to do that, perfectly illustrated by the scientific theories you presented to me which I debunked.  Instead they'd rather rely on dodgy science and unjustified criticism's of the IPCC, which you vaguely mentioned but failed to specify, and fallacies about how science was wrong once so it must be wrong now.  And now on to one of those fallacies...

The Ice Age Fallacy - 'scientists showed concerns about global cooling which did not materialise, and there is therefore no need to heed current scientific concerns about global warming.'
The facts - The vast majority of climate papers in the 1970s predicted warming.  Peterson 2008 was a study of 68 scientific studies on Global Cooling from 1965 to 1979.  The results were:-
62% predicted warming
10% predicted cooling
28% had no stance
The fact is that around 1970 there were 6 times as many scientists predicting a warming rather than a cooling planet.

Global warming vs climate change - There have long been claims that some unspecified "they" has "changed the name from 'global warming' to 'climate change'". In reality, the two terms mean different things, have both been used for decades, and the only individual to have specifically advocated changing the name in this fashion is a global warming 'skeptic'.  'Global warming' refers to the long-term trend of a rising average global temperature.  'Climate change', again as the name suggests, refers to the changes in the global climate which result from the increasing average global temperature.
For example, a seminal climate science work is Gilbert Plass' 1956 study 'The Carbon Dioxide Theory of Climatic Change' (which coincidentally estimated the climate sensitivity to a doubling of atmospheric carbon dioxide at 3.6¬∞C, not far off from today's widely accepted most likely value of 3¬∞C).  Barrett and Gast published a letter in Science in 1971 entitled simply 'Climate Change'.  The journal 'Climatic Change' was created in 1977 (and is still published today).  The IPCC was formed in 1988, and of course the 'CC' is 'climate change', not 'global warming'.  There are many, many other examples of the use of the term 'climate change' many decades ago.  There is nothing new whatsoever about the usage of the term.

Lord Monkton is not a qualified climatologist.  He is a former journalist, public speaker and hereditary peer.  You could give some quotes from him but you don't.  So I will:-
"Those who warn of the dangers of climate change should be jailed".
"There is no "causative link" from CO2-concentration to global average temperature".  Most deniers would I think actually disagree with him on that one.  Why you would hold him up an example I don't know, especially with the mess he made of interpreting the IPCC temperature calculations as I pointed out in an earlier comment.

Marc Morano - Also not a qualified climatologist.  Memorable quotes:-
Described Greta Thunberg as an "autistic prophet". He retweeted criticisms of her that center on her autism.
"We should kick scientists when they're down. They deserve to be publicly flogged".  Such a lovely man.  A real role model for the climate change denial scene.

Greta Thunberg is an activist, not a climate scientist.  I'm not sure how I feel about her in terms of whether she's doing more harm than good but honestly start paying more attention to what climate scientists say, and not politicians and activists.

In terms of science being settled this is one of the problems of the misconceptions about science in the general public.   No science is ever ‚Äúsettled‚Äù; science deals in probabilities, not certainties. When the probability of something approaches 100%, then we can regard the science, colloquially, as ‚Äúsettled‚Äù.  With things like the theory of the sun orbiting the Earth, we didn't have the technology to confirm this one way or another, they were theories.  Once we did and confirmed it with a high probability there were still deniers for quite a while who wouldn't accept it.  Gravity is an example of something that we are learning more and more about.
Scientists have been predicting AGW, with increasing confidence, for decades (indeed, the idea was first proposed in 1896).  As science learned more about the climate system, a consensus gradually emerged. Many different lines of inquiry all converged on the IPCC‚Äôs 2007 conclusion that it is more than 90% certain that anthropogenic greenhouse gases are causing most of the observed global warming.  What about the remaining uncertainties? Shouldn‚Äôt we wait for 100% certainty before taking action? Outside of logic and mathematics, we do not live in a world of certainties. Science comes to tentative conclusions based on the balance of evidence. The more independent lines of evidence are found to support a scientific theory, the closer it is likely to be to the truth. Just because some details are still not well understood should not cast into doubt our understanding of the big picture: humans are causing global warming.

text: Global Warming is a farce. BUT Global Climate Change is not. It's Climate Change, not Warming. Nevertheless, the world always has cried about China supposedly being the biggest contributor to climatic change due to their heavy reliance on burning coal for power, and having no regulations upon emissions whatsoever, YET - This very chart proves otherwise. In fact, the US overtook the UK while the UK still had the mass majority of it's "empire" intact! Think about that - The UK still had almost every single place they ever took over at their peak of dominance politically in the world, yet STILL got quickly surpassed by the US, while the US at that time had about 60% of it's current land & water claims. How sad is that! So whenever the US, UK, France, Germany, etc all cry out "China! China is the one who has bee polluting by far the most, especially in particulates and emissions!" Know it's a lie. I am confident in some ways China has led, and probably still leads in the pollution game, again, look to their thicker than pudding smog all over there. BUT, in this case with CO2? They're only very recently in second behind the US, and it's not even remotely close in total carbon emissions between them.

text:
The thing about carbon emission is that the Developed West is constantly pointing fingers at countries that are still developing and saying that because of the fast pass economic growth, countries such as India, China, Brazil and Mexico are the ones to blame. But what are these countries supposed to do? Yes, they should switch from fossil fuels to greener energy but is that going to be done overnight? These countries combined take almost half of the general population of the world. Are they simply going to stop feeding their people?

The west pretends as if their development history was green and harmless. But the fact is, they have already been through this phase and they did nothing either. Now that they have been out of this phase, they just start to point fingers at countries that are still struggling to feed its people. How hypocritical is that? Show some compassion and sympathy.

text:
¬†@Karthik KV¬†, That figure would translate to 5 parts per 1000 if my math is correct. Convert to parts per a million, since that is what it is usually measured in, and we have 5,000 ppm. Currently, according to the experts, our atmosphere has a little more than 400 ppm of CO2. Green house owners try to triple that to form a more ideal atmosphere for the growth of plants. In fact from the studies I have seen the benefit to plants only starts tapering off at somewhere between 3 to 4,000 ppm and CO2 levels don't even start making people drowsy until 10,000 ppm. The facts are that we could use at least 1,000 ppm more than we currently have for proper care for plants. 
It isn't rising very fast either. Somewhere around 260 years ago CO2 levels were at around 280 ppm. Even with an exponential curve of increase we are unlikely to see more than a 50 ppm increase within the next 12 years. All of this can be verified. Farther, Based on fossil records and scientific analyses we know roughly what CO2 levels were thousands of years ago and what global average temperatures were over the same period. little to no correlation has been found between the two.

text:
Global warming is a complete scam 
Here is the facts 

1. Record Ice

In 2014 there was¬†record sea ice in Antarctica¬†¬†in fact a global warming¬†expedition got stuck in it. Arctic sea ice has also made a nice¬†comeback in 2014. The Great lakes had record ice¬†Lake Superior only had 3 ice free months in 2014. You‚Äôd think that in the hottest year ever that ice would be melting like¬†Al Gore said.

2. Record Snow

2014 saw¬†record snowfall¬†in many areas, remember when they said that global warming would cause snow to disappear and¬†children won‚Äôt know what snow is.

3. Record Cold

In 2014 we saw all kinds of¬†cold records¬†remember the¬†Polar Vortex?¬†You‚Äôd think that we‚Äôd be breaking all kinds of heat records in ‚Äúthe hottest year ever‚Äù

4. Oceans Are Rising Much Less Than Predicted

Al Gore predicted that oceans would rise 20 feet by 2100, it looks like were on track for about a foot. 80% of the tide gauges show less rise than the official ‚Äúglobal average‚Äù.¬†Many tide gauges show no rise in sea level, and almost none show any acceleration over the past 20 years.

5. Polar Bears Are Thriving

You‚Äôd think that Polar Bears would really be in trouble in 2014 ‚Äúthe hottest year ever‚Äù but¬†they are thriving

6. Moose Are Making A Comeback

A few years ago the moose population in Minnesota dropped rapidly and they immediately¬†blamed global warming, then they¬†did a study¬†and found out it was actually wolves that were killing the moose. Wolves have been taken off the endangered species list and are now endangering other species so they opened a wolf hunting season in Minnesota and the moose are coming back. It turns out it had¬†nothing to do with global warming¬†in fact the years when the moose population declined were¬†some very cold ones.

7. 99% of Scientists don‚Äôt believe in Catastrophic Man-Made Global Warming

You‚Äôve probably heard over and over that 99% of scientist believe in global warming well the¬†opposite is true.¬†That talking point came from a study where only¬†75 scientists said they believe¬†in global warming on the other hand over¬†31,000 scientists have signed a petition¬†saying they don‚Äôt believe in Catastrophic Man-Made Global Warming.

8. Nature produces much more CO2 than man

In 2014 NASA finally launched a satellite that measures CO2 levels around the globe. They assumed that most of the CO2 would be coming from the industrialized northern hemisphere but much to their surprise it was coming from the¬†rainforests in South America, Africa and China

9. It Isn‚Äôt Actually the Warmest Year.

If you look at the satellite data¬†2014 was not the warmest year ever¬†in fact there has been no global warming for over 18 years. The Reason they can say it‚Äôs the warmest year is because they are using the ground weather station data which is heavily influenced by the Urban Heat Island effect,¬†many of which are near pavement. Even still they had to cherry pick that data to get at the warmest year ever and it is only the warmest by only¬†two-100ths of a degree¬†within a dataset that has a variability of a half of a degree. The fact they they had to ignore accurate data and fudge sketchy data to push their agenda proves (IMHO) that climate change is a hoax.

10. The Hypocrisy of the Main Players

One of the main reasons you can tell that global warming is a hoax is that the main purveyors of global warming live lifestyles opposite of what they preach, they all own multiple large homes and yachts and they fly around the world in private jets pushing their propaganda. Not to mention some people such as Al Gore actually profit from Carbon Taxes and other green energy laws. If they actually believed what they preached they would be leading quite different lives.

The truth is climate change is a complete scam big governments big businesses and the mainstream media are making a lot of money and power from brainwashing fear mongering people and the government and media are using global warming to distract people from real problems

text:
This is very deceptive. Cumulative production in the past is irrelevant. Current production rates are what count. CO2 produced in the past has already been recycled multiple times. That's why it's called the carbon cycle. CO2 produced 10 years ago has Zero effect on atmospheric CO2 levels of today.
CO2 production is very closely correlated with economic activity. The strongest economic countries, with the highest standard of living will out of necessity have the highest CO2 emissions. A vibrant economy demands energy - enormous quantities of it. Without energy, economies collapse and the standard of living collapses along with it. 

Wind and solar are wholly inadequate for powering an industrial society, they are simply too expensive and consume way to much real estate. That basically leaves fossil fuels and nuclear - both which are under attack in the USA. 

China's CO2 production has skyrocketed since 2001 and is now roughly double that of the USA. USA CO2 production continues to decline. China has its nuclear power generation plans back on track, with large numbers of new plants planned or already under construction. It is estimated than China will become the worlds #1 nuclear power producer within 10 years.
The trend is clear - the USA is on track for economic decline and decreased standard of living, while China is poised for exactly the opposite. That's great if you live in China, not so great if you live in the USA.

author: GoodFodder

text:
¬†@GoodFodder¬† If you look at seasonal CO2 composition in the atmosphere (Keeling curve) you'll begin to understand how much CO2 gets recycled by photosynthesis. Each year in the month of May the CO2 levels peak, and then start to drop rapidly as vegetation begins to flourish with spring temperatures. The effect is most pronounced in the northern hemisphere because that is where most of the land masses (and vegetation) are. The opposite seasons on the southern hemisphere have little effect because of that fact. When you examine the seasonal declines on the curve you can that they are almost as large as the increases, so the only way that CO2 levels can continue to climb is through continued upward pressure. If that upward pressure is reduced beyond the rate of photosynthesis conversion, CO2 levels drop rapidly. This means that current CO2 emission levels which are producing the upward pressure are by far the most relevant to any upward trend.
You admit that the standard of living collapses without adequate energy sources to power it's economy. However the concern about food and shortages it completely based upon political/environmentalist fear mongering. There is absolutely no demonstrable negative correlation between warmer temperatures and food production or CO2 levels and food production. The undeniable fact is that exactly the opposite is true. It's not a fact that is even rationally disputable. More tropical areas with warmer temperatures and more rainfall have vastly greater vegetation growth rates and greater food production. Bottom line: Warmer = Life flourishes; Colder = Life struggles

text: The math is simple: and anyone can find these numbers on the internet in various articles or even Physics documentaries about alternative energy that have aired over the years.  To achieve net zero CO2 emissions by 2050, the world would need to deploy 3 Turkey Point Nuclear plants worth of carbon free energy every two days as of Sept. 30, 2019 and continuing to 2050.  At the same time, the same Turkey Power Plants worth of Fossil Fuel energy would have to be decommissioned everyday from Sept. 30, 2019 and continuing to 2050.  So until one of you climate change activists actually invent and build a workable Fusion Power Plant you aren't helping a damn thing.  You are just bitching and whining and wanting someone else to do the job for you because you feel entitled to this Eutopian idea about how Earth should be.  If you are so serious about this, do something other than protesting and blockading/shutting down industry that can allow us to make the Investment to "Fund" this research.  Nope, just shut everything off for us working folks scraping by, all the while anyone that champions themselves as a Environmentalist gets to keep turning their lights on, fire up the stove, watch 4K Netflix, own a 4000 plus sqft house that isn't Net Zero at all.  The hypocrisy is unreal.  Quit crying about it to government and industry and invent/create something yourselves and build it up.  Can't do that without emitting Co2, so to Pat yourselves on the back you want it handed to you on a silver platter by Government.  Do any of you climate champions live a Net Zero Co2 lifestyle?  I really doubt it.  Until you do, pissssss offfffff!

text: ¬†@Rod Devereaux¬† Before the¬†industrial revolution, the¬†CO2¬†content in the air remained quite steady for thousands of years. Natural¬†CO2¬†is not static, however. It is generated by natural processes, and absorbed by others. Although our output of 29 gigatons of¬†CO2¬†is tiny compared to the 750 gigatons moving through the¬†carbon cycle¬†each year, it adds up because the land and ocean cannot absorb all of the extra¬†CO2. About 40% of this additional¬†CO2¬†is absorbed. The rest remains in the¬†atmosphere, and as a consequence, atmospheric¬†CO2¬†is at its highest level in 15 to 20 million years. (A natural change of 100ppm normally takes 5,000 to 20,000 years. The recent increase of 100ppm has taken just 120 years).

text: ¬†@David James¬† I can confirm that there is a reason why Germany and USA are so high up on the list. To the time of industrial revolution, the German Kaiserreich and USA were the industrial powerhouses, making a lot more money than those countries (India, China...) that were the agrar powerhouses. The economy and how things worked all changed at that time as Germans, Americans but also British people invented a lot of new machines. Only many years later, scientist discovered the problem behind the industrialization of the world. And only then, the countries began to produce a little bit less CO2 or at least that goes for Germany and other countries in the European union. This will actually continue as they signed the clima agreement in Paris (even though I (a german citizen) know that my country isn't doing that well with it but we try (sadly not our conservative leaders(only the greens and some other left wing progressive parties really know what to do)))

author: Buuhan

text: ¬†@Buuhan¬† Time will tell. The scottish had a referendum and a poll saying they wanted to stay and I'm part Scottish and concur. What's your overall view on Britain btw?
author: David James

text: ¬†@David James¬† I think that your government is kind of messy and I don't see Boris Johnson as a good politician. Of course it could be good for Britain to exit and be a country with a system like that from Singapore but I see it as a high risk maneuver. If it comes to non-political stuff I actually like British culture and English is also my favorite language to speak even though German on the other hand is a better language for poetry or just lyric overall. What makes me a bit concerned is the past of the British and how they keep some of their colonies but I guess that is something that other countries have too. Another point of why I don't like the Brexit is a personal thing I have going on, I know that there are people calling the European Union a 4th Reich or something in that way. I personally disagree to call myself a true proud German, I see myself more as an European which is something I wish a lot more people would do (my dream is to actually have some kind of European Union but even more together for the whole world(no matter if there is culture clash since we all relay on human rights no matter what culture and we all just want peace)). Or maybe it's all just something marked in my head as a German since our hymn starts with "Einigkeit und Recht und Freiheit..." which translates into "unity and right and freedom...".
author: Buuhan

text:
¬†@Buuhan¬† Fair enough.
What colonies? The Commonwealth is free to join or leave for any of the current members and the territories we have voted to stay with us.
25% of the world was united under the British Empire, which is the most united Humanity had been in all of recent history, even if it wasn't perfect. A lot of British people don't really think of themselves as European either, as we arn't on the continent. It's like the quote from a 1930s newspaper that joked, "Fog in the English Channel, continent isolated."

The EU politicians say they have eyes for Africa and want a new form of Empire, as well as an Army to defend against Russia, China, and the US. With most of the political power of the EU being headed by Germany it probably does look worrying to some people.
author: David James

text: ¬†@David James¬† That's not really true. European Union (especially Germany) pays a lot of money to develop African countries and Germany's military is literal shit except for maybe tanks. If you have one functional fighting jet you are an actual threat to Germany since we only have like 5 functioning fighting jets.
author: Buuhan

text: ¬†@Buuhan¬† So do a lot of other countries. I'm on about the EU military proposal which includes all members militaries combined. It is true what I said. It would also be true that if the EU merged into 1 super state like the US then Germany could increase its military production as simply a part of that much larger nation state. It wouldn't be difficult to say that this new nation needed more defences and so on. Especially if it started to move into Africa for whatever reasons it claims, where force projection would be required.
author: David James

text: ¬†@David James¬† Well, I don't think it's going to happen like this. Even if politicians say some things that can be misinterpreted, people won't let it happen. We all just want peace and a 4th Reich is especially unrealistic for the Germans if you consider a 4th Reich as something with nationalism (people even hate their own country because of their country's past). I think people see everything too negative, do we really always have to think about what war could happen and how things could escalate? The European Union is built up by many democracies which nobody wants to lose (except for far right wing) and even though there's a lot of propaganda out there in EU, US or China and sometimes you just don't really know what to trust. I believe in a future where we can actually live in peace and nobody harms one another. To achieve that future I think that unity is needed to stop the conflicts so that everybody works together to actually save humanity.
author: Buuhan

text: ¬†@Buuhan¬† Theres some contradiction in your messages there. Also, if you want peace and prosperity, then be a centrist not a far left or far right idiot. Super nationalism for a super state like the EU would ultimately take over from old nationalism anyways, people are tribal by nature.
author: David James

text: ¬†@David James¬† I wouldn't consider myself as far left or far right anyways but in Germany the centrists are just bullshit. Angela Merkel had times where she was kind of good but nowadays in times of digitalisation, her party disappoints me pretty much. Since I'm only 16 years old I couldn't vote but I would probably vote for something more left than right. The centrists don't really care about climate change but more about economy, the far rights care even less about climate change and they have a lot of racists in their party (especially against Muslims). The far left actually supports my opinion more but I wouldn't vote for them. I think I would vote for 'Die Partei' which is a comedian party that is more left. It actually presents a pretty good picture for me even though they kinda make fun of politics there is always a true message behind their statements.
author: Buuhan

text: ¬†@Buuhan¬† Your only a kid. Far left radicalism isn't the way. Also define far right, as that gets thrown around a lot now a days, to the point centrist are considered far right for simply disagreeing with far leftist sentiments.
author: David James

text: ¬†@David James¬† Yo, I'm not radical whatsoever. It's probably different in your country but in my country the centrists are making too much wrong decisions, the people are disappointed (including me) but I am not someone that goes on streets and damages cars etc. It's just that I see a better way in more left (not far left) than in the opposite direction while the centrists are only disappointing me.
author: Buuhan

text:
¬†@Buuhan¬† When did I say you were radical, i said don't go down that route.
Yeah here it's probably quite a bit different from what I can tell from what I've seen and you've said so far.
So your centre-left then? That's fine but like I said, try not to slip further and further left. A lot of kids seem to be going that way now which is quite worrying.
author: David James

text: ¬†@David James¬† Don't worry and I'm sorry but it just sounded like it though xD. I won't go down the far left route as I know that there are people out there (also in my class in school) that are actually pretty extreme with women's rights, climate change and how they have to present their sexuality and their way of life to everybody and saying that it's the only way to do it. But what makes me actually think that humanity can be saved are the people that actually are also my friends because we all have the kind of same opinion about politics. I also think they would all vote for 'Die Partei' too but I'm not sure.
author: Buuhan

text: ¬†@Buuhan¬† Ah okay, glad to hear it lol. You'd still want differing opinions though at times or it would be an echo chamber and 1 party state. What you need most is for different groups to be a to share their ideas for healthy debate.

Volume containing 75% of the atmosphere's mass: 4/3 œÄ (6,384km)¬≥ - 4/3 œÄ (6,371km)¬≥ = 6,644,000,000 km¬≥
Fact: air has a density of 1.225 kg/m¬≥ at sea level and 15¬∞C
Total mass of the atmosphere up to 13 km: 6,644,000,000,000,000,000 m¬≥ * 1.225 kg/m¬≥ = 8,139,000,000,000,000,000‚Ä¨ kg = 8,139,000,000,000,000 tons
Total emissions summed from chart: 1,238,400,000,000 tons
Result: 75% of the Earth's atmosphere is 6,572 times heavier than that. And that's not accounting for the carbon absorbed by plants, oceans, and geological processes.


Conclusion: our human Neanderthal brain is incapable of dealing with such scales and must apply tools (e.g. maths) to help understand.

text:
Jan 2018


 China‚Äôs Emissions: More Than U.S. Plus Europe, and Still Rising

 This week, as they gather in Davos for the annual global gabfest, world leaders continue to see China as a major force in that fight. Yet new figures show a complicating development: China‚Äôs emissions of climate-changing greenhouse gases may be rising again.

China ‚Äî which already emits more carbon from burning fossil fuels than the United States and Europe combined ‚Äî saw electricity use jump last year as its economy accelerated. Much of the extra demand was met by burning more coal, a particularly dirty fuel. Oil use has also risen as China has become the world‚Äôs largest car market, and so has natural gas consumption.

Experts say one annual increase doesn‚Äôt indicate China is returning to an era when its emissions grew by leaps and bounds. But the increase illustrates the challenges and compromises Beijing must juggle if it wants to stoke its economy and at the same time keep its environmental promises.

1800: 283 ppm of CO2
1850: 285 ppm of CO2
1900: 296 ppm of CO2
1950: 311 ppm of CO2
2000: 369,55 ppm of CO2
2016 (hottest recorded year): 404,24 ppm of CO2
2019: 411,39 ppm of CO2

text:
The burden of lowering emissions and mitigating climate change should be based on wealth and economic development NOW in 2019.  While this animation of graphs is informative and well done, I don't think it should be taken as guide as to which countries should shoulder the burden of reducing carbon emissions and mitigating climate change.  


People born in the US, UK, and Western Europe didn't ask to be born into the countries that became industrialized first.  And just because your country had a level of economic development on par with those of Sub-Saharan African countries 50 years ago, doesn't absolve your country from shouldering global environmental responsibility NOW.  There's too many ultra rich people TODAY in Shanghai, Beijing, Singapore, Seoul, Mumbai, Dubai, etc. etc. peeing in gold-plated toilets (I'm being hyperbolic) not for them to feel as responsible for environmental and climate change solutions as their counterparts in the US, UK, France, Germany, Canada, Australia, etc. 


Conversely there are too many people in smaller industrial cities and rural fossil fuel-dependent towns in the US, UK, and Western Europe that have been left behind by the global economy NOT to have empathy and keep them in mind when crafted environmental and climate change policy.

text:
Top five co2 producing countries 1. CHINA  2. USA  3. INDIA  4. RUSSIA  5. JAPAN
China and India are both developing nations. Soon India will surpass the USA in co2.
While the USA IS conscious of the problem and at least being self-aware and trying to do something about it on both national and individual levels, India is doing little, and China is doing nothing.
As their production and population increase, so too will their co2 pollution, exponentially. 
While India may have some small level of self-awareness about it and is making some small efforts to mitigate it, China seems to care less and is apparently doing nothing about it. 
So when environmentally concerned people target America as being the main offenders and thus the ones who can "fix" the problem... they are being egregious. If they really want to tackle the main offenders, they should be focusing their efforts on China more than America... and soon India more than America too...

text: This is not accurate. It's amazing how much the statistics can be twisted or exploited to achieve whatever conclusions you want. Currently Canada's contribution to the  global emissions output is at 2% while Saudi Arabia's is 4.5%. Canada's is automatically dealt with by virtue of the vast tracts of trees it has which absorb more carbon than the nation produces while Saudi Arabia has no trees and is one Middle Eastern nation that has committed to DOUBLING its carbon emissions over a period of thirty years, in the faces of those who are concerned about climate change. Since I learned this I am dubious of any information that seeks to play down the huge carbon footprint of Middle Eastern oil-producing nations. The highest producers per capita are in the Mlddle East so the more we try to get USA, Canada, etc. to cut down the more the market is open for Middle Eastern oil producers to fill the gap and keep polluting. Deal with them FIRST and hold them accountable.

text: I don‚Äôt believe the U.S has THAT many emissions but the reason for those emissions is the U.S industrial make-up. Us Americans were the first to mass produce motorized vehicles, and we were the first to have planes which are also responsible for a lot of emissions. But in recent years, laws on emissions have changed and most factories were closed down. Now most of our imports are from China and India. I believe America shouldn‚Äôt have been that high. Because other countries have followed in our footsteps but have larger or smaller, inferior populations. The U.S isn‚Äôt one of the most polluted places. China and India are. But either way, those numbers were only going up. The only way to help our planet is to reduce the increase in emissions. Yet that is nearly impossible to do because we have a growing population. Also, many countries that could make it on to this list were not there.

text:
Which is totally justified.
China is currently producing the most co2 per year out of all countries around the world and they only keep producing more every single year, so it's fair to blame them.
And India might not be the number 2 in terms of co2 production per year, but they will be soon enough, so it's fair to blame them as well.
So as soon as India becomes the number 2 on this list, China and India will be the two biggest producers of co2 per year.
Also, keep in mind that this video is about the total amount of co2 emitted by each country in history, but what has happened in the past doesn't matter right now, the only thing that matters right now is how much co2 each country produces per year, and although the USA can certainly be blamed too, China and India can and will be blamed even more in the future.

text: It‚Äôs more the waste that‚Äôs dangerous, even when you can‚Äôt get anymore energy from it it‚Äôs still radioactive and there is no permanent storage
author: Liam Mclean

text: ¬†@Liam Mclean¬† Iceland, a country with 330,000 people, surrounded by water with a land mass larger than Ireland. This will not work on a larger scale. While it is true, products will become more efficient. Not at the rate I think you might believe. Electric motors are already around 95% thermal efficiency and the gains to be made are minimal Sure we will likely get new technology that completely changes the way a device works and makes it more efficient. But I do not think it will be earth shattering. And to coincide with that increase in efficiency, we are going to have an increase in demand. More things are going to use electricity, the vehicles will be one of he biggest users. One tesla vehicle charge is like charging your phone 4000 times. So when our entire vehicle fleet is electric, we are going to have some problems. I think fully renewable electricity is a pipedream. But hey, maybe they drastically reduce the cost of a windmill and increase its energy production
author: Yolo Swaggins

text: Yolo Swaggins even a 1-5% better efficiency would make a huge difference believe me. The introduction of smart energy meters will also lower the energy consumption of a nation. Sweden is another country with almost 100% RE usage. Scotland can power itself 100% from wind power
author: Liam Mclean

text: Yolo Swaggins Hydrogen power is also another renewable energy source that cars are more likely to run off of in the future. Electric cars are likely just a stop gap. Hydrogen has one of the highest energy densities of any fuel meaning it can produce more power than nuclear
author: Liam Mclean

text: ¬†@Liam Mclean¬† Hydrogen is not the solution, Ive seen so many scientists debating this. Hydrogen is extremely energy hungry when it comes to the separation of the hydrogen atoms from the 02 and also in terms of storage. Takes a lot of energy to liquify hydrogen. Also fuel cells are extremely inefficient. There is no reason to use hydrogen over electricity except for the fill up time.

I am in Australia, where the land mass is near the  size of China but with a Taiwan population. Do you think Australia is entitled to the same emission as China? A logical and normal person would not think so. Second, China has been enforcing policies to reduce environmental issues, including smogs. Regarding recyclables and non recyclables, they still need to work hard to reduce plastic production and use, but nonetheless many aspects are moving on the positive size, which I also mentioned on a separate post. Here in developed nations, for so long we took things for granted and sent junks to developing nations. I am glad that China now refusing those junks, I think other developing nations should do the same. Again what happened here in Australia, we are banning the use of plastic bags etc. I think the world can only improve and sustain with collective efforts, China bashing helps no body, except ill minded people talking trash for ugly political reasons. And as a oversea Chinese, who do have quite a few right winged friends from Taiwan myself, I have seen worse.
author: Y Hong

text: Y Hong for the first bit of your statement I was agreeing with Scott that unless we all reduce green house emissions we are screwed and acknowledged the fact that a small country that goes completely green or in other words removing their carbon footprint to a minimum often gets canceled out by other countries that instead of reducing emissions they are creating more making their effort feel pointless. Reducing emissions is a group effort and unless everyone does it other countries feel as if they have no reason to lower emissions as their efforts are negligible and you are back at square one when the other countries don‚Äôt give a shit.
author: Deavan

text:
Y Hong for the part on whether I think Australia should be able to have higher emissions my stance is rather strange. I believe every person is entitled to the same level of emissions as everyone else but I also believe that if fossil fuels or pollutants that cause air pollution are involved that initial statement is redacted but it wouldn‚Äôt be if clean sources of energy are used to get that energy. With the use of air polluting energy forms I agree that in Australia with a very small population and land mass they would be able to have higher emissions as environmental problems wouldn‚Äôt occur in as bad of a scale as in Chinese cities where smog occurs because of it.
So with your question on Australia being able to higher emissions I agree the average Australian should be allowed to have a higher amount. However if clean energy sources are used that don‚Äôt create smog are used I am all in favor of China being able to use as much energy as the Australian. In other words if the amount of air pollution from it causes bad air conditions it should be regulated until the energy becomes clean and smog won‚Äôt occur then you can go crazy and have the emissions of an Australian.
author: Deavan

text: Y Hong the recyclable and non recyclable stance I align with you.  I was simply stating that non recyclable garbage is not responsible for smog as it just sits till it decomposes and is not processed by a machine into another object that causes coal or fossil fuel to be used which then pollutes the air. With your garbage being sent to developing countries stance I agree and sit in the same boat as you
author: Deavan

text: Y Hong just to let you know the developing countries take trash because it can be recycled into other materials and resold for money which also brings jobs. China is now at a point where doing that doesn‚Äôt much benefit anymore and just pollutes a large amount. Every developing country will see that as profitable till it has no reason to do so and does not benefit as much as it does negatively so it will happen again and again and the cycle repeats because of economics it‚Äôs a sad thing to see but it‚Äôs capitalism at work and how a country develops into a developed country
author: Deavan

text:

author: idk what my name should be

text: ¬†@idk what my name should be¬† Well you could tell them when new countries are born and when countries loose a territory and yes it's lying, for one it paints a picture in peoples head of a false history that these countries where around back then (the flags don't help either) when these countries weren't responsible for the pollution shown the current overlords where and this should reflect that as it waters down the impact some countries had on global warming like Australia is in the top ten when it didn't even exist as a dominion of Britain until 1901 placing the blame on the Australians and not the British.
author: The Glueman

text:
¬†@The Glueman¬† again..it'd over complicate things, and it isn't the most important thing about the video anyway

Edit: after reading over your comment again, no it is not lying, the pollution is still coming from that general area, the video isn't making a history lesson, it doesn't need to be exact on everything. And sure, it could have told them when a new country was named, but let's face it, it really does not matter
author: idk what my name should be

text: ¬†@idk what my name should be¬† When a video or anything starts to involve history, you bet it becomes a history lesson for anyone who are unfamiliar with the time period as this would be the first info they would have on it so it's important to be exact to not spread misinformation, and just because the pollution coming from an area where countries exist today doesn't mean they should be listed as their own countries if they didn't exist back then, after all the question was "What Countries Are Most Responsible For Global Warming?" so yes it would be lying to blame countries that didn't exist, it's not asking about the area, it's asking about which country/which ruling body is responsible and if you label countries that didn't exist/had nothing to do with the pollution then yes, that is lying.
author: The Glueman

text: ¬†@The Glueman¬† but no one is asking for a history lesson..all this video is trying to do is spread awareness on global warming. Few people would wsnt to learn about countries in the 1900s from a youtube video. The MAIN point is about global warming, sure it involves history, but the main focus isn't to teach people about history. It isn't lying tho, because the main focus of the video is about global warming, it would be lying if the main focus is inaccurate, but the main point of the video is not about countries existing in previous centuries.
author: idk what my name should be

text: ‚Äã¬†@idk what my name should be¬† ‚ÄãAnything is a lesson if it's telling someone something they didn't know it's not about, and most people will absorb this subconsciously as its new info, spreading misinformation which is bad. The main focus is who is the most responsible for global warming and its disingenuous to blame countries that didn't even exist, which makes the main focus inaccurate because they didn't account for history, so you get a skewed view of the problem.
author: The Glueman

text: ¬†@The Glueman¬† it's not innacurate tho. It's using modern geography to determine where the pollution is coming from, as in what area the country would be in back then. The video isn't trying to teach you the history of the geography, it's trying to tell you how pollution has been put out over the years, seriously it doesn't matter that much that the history is innacurate, as i said, it would be lying if they were lying about the actual pollution statistics. This is to raise awareness on pollution, not teach you about which countries existed or didn't exist back then. It does not NEED the history of the countries "existence". No one is gonna remember what these little details are, so there's no point
author: idk what my name should be

text: ¬†@idk what my name should be¬† It IS inaccurate, it's not talking about geographic area it's talking about countries that's why the title says countries and not geographic area and so yes it's trying to tell you which COUNTRIES have polluted and if a country didn't exist or if the statistic isn't showing the pollution for the entire area the country controlled at a particular time then YES it is LYING because its not the ACTUAL pollution statistics of the country so that is why its important to get this right because otherwise, it's LYING. Also, most of this stuff is common knowledge like the USSR collapsed in 1991 or Poland didn't exist until after ww1 or if you don't know something maybe a simple 5-second google could tell you when the country existed. It REALLY isn't hard to get this right.

text:
Anything else being said in this thread does not matter. India is ready to let go of all historical wrongs and tackle climate change at the cost of her own growth. It is the only big nation to score high on the climate change performance index last year. Because it is such a large nation and still has nowhere near peaked its emissions, this commitment in policy and at ground matters. Not for the world, though. All the world knows about us is that we shit on the streets and we neglect dogs. Which is precisely why we are going to resist the western narrative and take it back home.

Anyway, you have the orange man baby on the other hand crying about how much tax money is being spent on global warming, something that does not even exist, and pulling away from what little we have been able to build through the last decades, quashing whatever meaningful progress has been made(read paris climate accords).

Dear muricans. Either your president knows something that the rest of the world does not, or he is a plain idiot, and making many of you look like that. Perhapa it is time to shed that thick skin of exceptionalism and point your sword of famed whataboutery at your own soul, and do some real, sweat inducing introspection. The world has grown weary of childish fits. From now on, just watch some hetalia and stop trying to whack/mould everyone into your image. It is not a perfect image as you seem to think, cause you are not god.
author: winter prince

text: ¬†@Kyle Jones¬† what's not true? Did I ever say we weren't 7th and were developed? That still doesn't change the fact we have an immense footprint and the potential to smash through any pollution the US or any other nation could have added to the earth, very quickly. Which is why this commitment, at the cost of sacrificing some growth, matters, and other notable nations should also adopt. We wouldn't be the third largest yearly emitter if only economic clout meant everything in the world.
author: winter prince

text:
¬†@Kyle Jones¬† ¬†Kyle Jones¬† 
It's not alarming at all considering we hold 1/7th of total humanity. We are not that underdeveloped, y'know. Most of our pollution comes from cars etc because govt has long since cracked down on industrial pollution, akin to some west european countries, even though it has not been nullified. I don't think we will ever come to a point where everyone has a car. Lack of land and problems of scale. At most, we might double our total urban area in the next 30-40 years, and then slowly plateau.
Meat is not that expensive here(especially chicken, what most eat). Some(Less than 25%) people are vegetarian because of religion, and most of these actually belong to the affluent class. Now historically we have been a dual agrarian-pastoral society, so the veganism could have springed from a desire to protect valuable livestock, also used in barter. We are, however, a food surplus nation. Always been barring some years in the British raj. Which is why the high population.
When someone says a nation is unable to feed its people they normally mean a food deficit/population beyond the carrying capacity of the land. People here(mostly some farmers and labourers) go hungry because of absence of proper minimum wage, minimum price for crops, crops procurement processes, middlemen, lack of enough land holding to till, etc. These are iniquities mired in history and much more complex to solve.

Anyway, so far India has been moving people straight to the service sector from the agro sector. If this pattern continues, there is nothing to worry. If it becomes a manufacturing hub, however, it does have the potential to supplant China as the largest polluter. I really hope and do not think that will happen. Because we at least have policies we have committed to and done some maths to let the world know what we will be doing in the bext decades, unlike some nations in the new world, which really pisses me off.

I don't want to force an argument, but it is obvious that you don't know much about the unique circumstances/peculiarities of India, and yet want to give advice, however good intentioned that may be. This majorly triggers us Indians, and with good reason. Please do research about all the countries if you want to understand them/find solutions, they are all unique.
author: winter prince

author: ritika chaudhuri

text:
¬†@Kyle Jones¬† You and I may have very different ideas of what good quality meat is. For a westerner, it would be well preserved, well certified, genetically modified(perhaps) meat. For me, it would be meat that is fresh and not unnecessarily pumped up with antibiotics and stuff(happens a lot in India). And it is pretty cheap and easily available. Almost all food in India is locally procured and fresh. We have a cultural predisposition against packaged food and it doesn't go at all with our cuisine. That may be the reason why packaged food is expensive here. At any rate, when the Indian market accepts a product, no matter how high the prices/costs are, they inevitably come rolling down a mountain. Countless prior examples.


I never said cars won't increase. I said they won't substantially increase, cause unless they are able to fly, our roads cannot handle it. At any rate, we are already moving towards electric cars, albeit slowly.


As for what I said, I stand by it. A statement like that still makes me believe you don't have enough experience to understand the Indian narrative/perspective no matter how many times you have been here or how many books you have read. More subjectivity is required, as they say, feeling is half the knowing. The western perspective usually tends to be subjective when it comes to them, and objective when it comes to others. This is heavily biased, but unfortunately, this is the prevalent narrative right now due to the globalization of English. Which brings me to my next point.


We are actually not that intolerant/impatient/soft skinned towards criticism. However, we are tired after centuries of seeing our history misconceived then belittled, our existence perverted then wished away, our achievements minimised then whitewashed(exactly the point of this thread). Which is why we now demand an alternative worldview that places us in the anthropocentric seat of worldview, just as nations such as China or Japan have been able to establish. Call it an academic war, if you will. Whatever good we do, is belittled, whatever bad we do, is magnified. Otherwise why would people criticize a country that is a leader in tackling climate change and faces huge risks from it rather than countries who are not ready to skin single pennies of unearned exploitation? I don't understand the suspicion towards india, when people are gushing over how climate friendly Sweden is. Both countries are leaders in environmental policy making. However, no matter what Sweden does is not going to make a real difference. It's what countries like China, India, AND the US do that are going to make a difference. India's accomplishments in this field therefore, should be given more attention to, and the other two made to follow suit by public opinion.


I know exactly what you mean. No extra pollution is good pollution, however small that may be, and India's emissions have definitely not peaked yet(we have been allowed till 2023, I think, to peak), but patterns of development are different for different countries. It is with good reason(China, Japan) that asian countries stress public transport rather than cars. It is cultural, there is a lack of natural resources and space available per capita, and problems, rather, advantages of scale, making public transport too affordable not to avail. The distances are short too, and there are a lot of other reasons. We are not a materialistic culture, and we can never afford to be, to sustain ourselves.


The definitions of modernity are also changing right as we speak. Frequent flights are not a marker of modernity(everywhere is not the US where places are too distant and passengers too few), and large, steam belching carbon factories have long ceased to be the ladders of development. Mobile phones, rather than computers rule the roost, and it seems like we are on the cusp of another industrial revolution. From that point of view, we are proud to be the largest data consuming country, and on the road to become a digital economy. New challenges in terms of environment are emerging, and it may have less to do with population. I don't think one should be too worried about carbon emissions anyway. We will probably fail our targets and them reabsorb the extra carbon somehow. Things like biodiversity loss are going to be bigger challenges in the coming days imo.


At any rate, we are a responsible nation. It is in our cultural spirit and even in our constitution to be a honorable and just nation. So don't worry, we got it under control.
author: winter prince

text: ¬†@R Boreds¬† ‡Æ®‡ØÄ ‡Æé‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡Æü‡Ææ ‡Æö‡Øä‡Æ≤‡Øç‡Æ≤‡Æµ‡Æ∞?
author: Smartphone Master

text:
‚Äã¬†@Kyle Jones¬† Again, I don't understand this obsession with 'good quality meat'. What constitutes good quality meat for you? How does it matter? Please explain.


About roads, if you have been to old Indian cities, you'd know the constraints with space. We have nearly 57% arable land, and it is crucial it remains so. Forest cover must not decrease either. Where do we end up with urbanising? Yes, total urban land, length and breadth of roads will increase, but it will never get to the point where it can handle one car per citizen. Look at Japan, who have similar circumstances, and the focus on public transportation there despite being one of the richest and most evolved economies. Also, I never said all cars are going to change to electric tomorrow. 15-25 years would be an optimistic timeline.


Think of me as an asshole if you would. Does not bother me. I'm not the one getting triggered and personally attacking people when things don't go my way. Anyway, I said all nations are quite dissimilar to all others, and the narrative that is dominant right now in academia is the anglo-american liberal one, due to various factors(triumph of capitalism, world wars, trade, english, democracy, etc), and this doctrine is home to people from GB and USA, often making them unable to identify with foreign ideologies, whereas people from everywhere else must acclimatize themselves with the anglocentric worldview as well as their home ideologies(nationalism for 2019 India, progress for the PRC, etc). That was why I said more subjectivity is needed. I never said Indian people shit gold/aren't subjective when it comes to their own country.


Criticise when little Jack makes a mistake, encourage him when he makes a cute family drawing. That is the dictum maintained with every other nation in the world except India(and sometimes China). We simply can't catch a break. No matter what the elephant does, no matter how much it has a heart of gold, people will be suspicious. SImply because it has the potential to wreak havoc if it ever wanted. This is actually self fulfilling. Tell Jack everyday that he is the son of a thief, and chances are he will grow up to become one.


If what we do bad should be magnified, same should be applied to what we do well. Environment would be one of them(cleanliness and soil pollution aside). Especially when the other two biggies are being irresponsible. I never said India was the leader, but it is one of them. No bones with Sweden, but I was pointing at how much attention it(all scandinavian nations) receives, while India usually being 'shown its place'(like is happening here) despite both doing well.


Again, let me point my finger at Japan. They're rich, but a lot less materialistic than the USA. China on the other hand is more materialistic despite being poorer. National culture is indeed a thing. It could also be attributed to problems of scale, there being more people and less space. Whatever it is, nations industrialise differently.


About phones/computers. You seem to think every problem has its roots in money/gdp per capita. The reason India chose mobile phones was the timing of the telecom revolution in India. Phones had already become the worldwide norm by then, and the role of computers is fast decreasing.


Every country, not just India, is on the cusp of an industrial revolution. Call it an information revolution, if that's what would make you look beyond the manufacturing sector. I. revolutions are also associated with paradigm shifts. One cannot judge/predict one with preexisting body of knowledge. No one would have guessed that Spain would fall and the tiny whimsical island nation called Engerland would change the world if they were left to work with only what knowledge was available before the 19th century. This is not to be overly optimistic/complacent, and other nations can as easily avail of the boons that are to come as India(despite having advantages like large population with lack of manufacturing depth/diversity, service expertise, etc). However, thinking the differences of today(gdp gap) will translate into differences of tomorrow almost completely identically, is the least to say, erroneous.


I was not belittling the importance of reducing emissions. However, with the present international structure and public opinion, we are in no way going to be able to keep the carbon balance sheet even. However, technology is progressing in this sector pretty fast, so we may soon have the capacity to reabsorb carbon from the atmosphere. We are more lost when it comes to what to do with the rapid bio diversity loss that is going to begin soon.
author: winter prince

text:
¬†@Kyle Jones¬† Now I get what you mean. Wonder why there are highly developed agro products/ non meat food processing industries in India(milk, crops, cottage cheese, etc), but not meat? Not because of money. We as a race have an irrational aversion to frozen/packaged meat. Yes, people from affluent backgrounds use more processed foods in the above mentioned sectors, and money is a factor there, but rich and poor alike hate processed meat. Our cuisine is quite heavy handed/blunt, and while there is delicacy, there is absolutely no space for subtlety. Fine meat isn't a thing here, and not because of money. It's just not something we enjoy.

Even in a highly developed state it won't be 1 car every 5 families. Either way, yes, it will rise significantly, and that is just inevitable.

Because your comment was just below mine, I assumed you were replying to me. If you weren't, we may have been arguing all along for naught.

" you are the one getting triggered about me saying things that are about India. Boohoo. And that‚Äôs you who‚Äôs tolerant and for thick skin? Maybe not. "
I'm not the one appending self righteous LOLs and Boohoo's after each sentence.

"You and I are not dissimilar at all, I‚Äôm sure when you have money you will buy nice things too. I‚Äôve traveled the world and have experiences more cultures than you have. I‚Äôm accepting and understand different ideologies. Just because you disagree with the fact I said India pollutes doesn‚Äôt mean I and don‚Äôt identify with different ideologies. "

Are Singapore and Dubai similar or dissimilar? The answer is both. One chooses to accentuate either the similarity or the difference. In this case, I chose the latter because you seemed to believe Indians will buy too much like say USA when they industrialise, which you latter said you didn't think. Again, look at Japan. Initially, they bought more, but it scaled down, and was never at the level of the US, despite being a much richer country.
FYI, I have  the money, and still choose to live as mundane a life as possible. I roam around with slippers and two year old shirts :p It lets me slip under the radar and observe people rather than be observed, also allowing me to be self dependent, no matter what life throws at me.
Also, I don't get how self certification(I have traveled and seen it all) can substitute logic and well reasoned arguments in a debate.
I never said India doesn't pollute. It pollutes quite heavily.

"You have been taught to hate the western world for a young age, because of history and how Britain dominated India for many years and then how USA have been causing wars  around the world for many years too. What they‚Äôve done has been wrong, no question about it but Indians carry an unbelievable grudge. Believe me, I‚Äôve experienced it first hand. "

Thank god we have been subjected to that. Otherwise there would have been no one to remember all those who gave their life trying to win self determination. Even now, the world pays token respect to 'ghandi', and that's all they know about the Raj.
Anyway, you are wrong. Everything here does not revolve around post colonialism. I have never been taught to hate the west(we aren't taught much world history in schools anyway) and I don't. I have also been subjected to internet rage from Brits who screamed at me that I should be thankful that their nation took up the 'white man's burden' and civilized our country, gave us english and railways and bla bla. I have been called streetshitter, Pajeet, etc. I don't go around thinking every brit is like that.
Negative emotions are way stronger than positive ones, and nothing proves that more than yt comments section. It's a den of frustrated demons that will suck out any good vibes you ever had, and will leave you dry.

"You are actually so wrong. Who is punishing India? Please explain who? Britain has a significant Indian population, is it them? America is it then? France? Germany? Who? Who is it you speak of?? America has an issue with anyone, not India. Don‚Äôt think your country is special. No one has a problem with India at all, they are just a huge country that have a huge impact on the environment. "

You misinterpreted punishment. In present world politics, punishment is criticism and negative propaganda. Just take a look at most available media/literature on India. It's overwhelmingly negative. The US decided to screw with the USSR post wwii with nothing but propaganda. Look where that left the USSR. Today everyone looks at Russia with suspicion(unless they are rabidly anti US like Serbia). It will take Russia at least 4-5 decades if they can ever mend their public image again.
author: winter prince

text:
¬†@Kyle Jones¬† "Sadly people don‚Äôt seem to commend countries on good behaviour, only bad. Like the west for example, they‚Äôve done good but only get pointed out the bad. They saved the world, twice (joint effort). But people don‚Äôt care about this, only the negative. "

Look, the current world is made of, by, and for the west. If you look at anything, producers of information consist of westerners, and care only about western consumers(because money has more value there), even though it is consumed worldwide. Do you watch Border and cheer Indian soldiers for protecting their homeland? But we all watch Private Ryan be saved his pals from those ebil germans and are made to feel as if we should feel proud when the US flag flies. We all wear suits and ties to workplace, we all headbob to Rihanna. As the world becomes more multipolar, I'm sure the contributions of the west shall be appreciated properly, but as of now, it's all west, and there's no lack of self-praise and narcissism. There are small pockets of change happening(like Churchill getting his overdue condemnation), but portraying it as a world unfair to the west would just be knee-jerk reactionism.

Like I said, there should be more subjectivity. The anglo saxons acted like the world was gonna end when the French revolution happened. Didn't happen. Same happened with the Bolshevik rev. I understand the antipathy liberalism has radical ideologies, but you need to understand that it is not shared to the same degree by the 'illiberal' world. That is why we don't thank you for 'saving the world' twice. We think the world wouldn't have ended with a few dictators, and we don't put so much stock in their capacity to oppress as faraway and huge lands as China or India successfully for a long time. You saved europe and the far east. Kudos and thank you for the whole of humanity. But not the whole world.

"Money does rule the world, unfortunately. However, I don‚Äôt think money is involved in everything but when the population of India is poor, it does. Especially considering In the future India won‚Äôt be poor and the population will become richer. 
Smart phones and laptops have taken over the traditional PC, I agree with this but to say it‚Äôs nothing to do with money is somewhat naive. I know I‚Äôm from the west and you‚Äôve got your Indian bias but you can agree with me on some things, after all there is more than one factor that contributes to decisions. "

There's also power, ideologies, and narrative(with the info revolution) that drive the world. Power is disproportionately important in the Indian context. If you said apple is not popular in India because of being overpriced vis a vis features, I'd agree. Smartphones over desktops, not so much. But yes, the laptop market has costs as a constraint from growing as much as it could.
author: winter prince

text:
¬†@Kyle Jones¬† "Then that‚Äôs clearly an information revolution not an industrial revolution. 
Why would no one guess Spain would fall? After all the heaviest defeats in the Anglo-Spanish war was from the Spanish and they were also defeated in the Spanish Armada. No clue who Engerland is but I‚Äôm assuming you mean Britain lol. Britain was dominant long before the 19th century so I‚Äôm not sure what you are on about? 
Spain weren‚Äôt even that strong, France were stronger and Britain had the strongest Navy. If Britain didn‚Äôt have its empire, it would of been France."

You're right about Spain, my bad. My thyroid is up and I was feeling dizzy when I wrote that lol. Think the first part of the age of exploration.

There is no reason an information revolution cannot be an industrial revolution, especially if it by default revolutionizes the modes of production and transportation. And if information becomes a commodity to be produced and consumed, even better. After all, the current etymology of 'industry' as it stands today, developed only after the industrial revolution. What's to say it won't undergo further change?

"Random now but do normal Indian folk hate richer Indians? Apparently most are stuck up and self absorbed. Also, what‚Äôs the situation with toilets in India? Are people still pooing in the street? Genuinely curious, not hating."
 
Normal Indian people are middle class. But either upper middle class or lower middle class. True middle class is fast becoming extinct. There's also a smaller, but big enough poor class, but they don't drive demand or consumption. They just produce things for no pay. This class does not have any class consciousness in the european sense(very specific exceptions aside-like farmer's agitations). They kind of admire the people above them, thinking they might be superior somehow to have gotten there and must have worked hard. So admiration+inferiority complex- a legacy of our history of casteism. At any rate, everyone, including even the most illiterate person, understands that there is limited resources to be shared by all, and the law of the land is supposed to be egalitarian. So the one that works the hardest gets it, no hard feelings involved. They are positive and motivate their children to achieve better futures for themselves. It's actually the rich that hate the poor, and refuse to look at them in other manners than one looks at vermin. The noveau riche are cool though, they don't hate the poor.

About the actual street shitting, that used to happen 8-10 years ago. Migrant laborers who came to work in cities slept in the open at night and let go of their bladders on the streets in the morning. Now they still sleep under the sky/overcrowded lodging, but avail of public toilets in the morning.
Now what's actually famous, is people letting go in the open/not in their bathrooms. Even two years ago when I caught a morning train I would see dozens of people squatting down if I looked outside in the wrong places(near villages or suburbs). Now I rarely see anyone do that, and I live in one of the northern states(West Bengal), so there's definitely been a sea change. Can't vouch for other states though.


(I had to put it in notepad and reply thrice so it would go through lol)
