text:
¬†@Kyle Jones¬† I'm missing out on fine meat and fine wine as much as you are missing out on Indian food and culture. Feel for you too bro.(Hope you can see how arrogant that sounded)

I was saying the same thing all along. Yes, it will rise substantially, but at/to a much lesser degree than most western countries.

It's patronizing to claim you know better than me why I wear those shirts. Mugging isn't a thing here. In my entire life I have never felt a fear of getting mugged, and I have crossed my fair share of dark alleyways at night and crowded hellholes.
I get scammed regardless due to my fair skin and the fact that I look like a pampered innocent man child. In here people actually get respect if they dress well/show their wealth. We still have a servile mentality. I already said that in the past reply. If you can't believe that, there's nothing I can do.

France does hate germany somewhat(before eu), and that hate was reciprocated. England never had skin in the game. It never had its women taken by the germans, its children killed, and then be told 'be thankful for your disciplining', and see that lie transplant the truth the world over, being believed by everyone.
author: winter prince

text: ¬†@Kyle Jones¬† as far as grudges are concerned it is because westerners generally don't like to admit a wrong was done. They tend to dismiss any introspection as western guilt and apologism and transfer all the guilt to their forefathers, while never missing out on mocking India for its present depredations caused by those same forefathers. Acknowledgements, if not aopogies, are needed to be made for both sides to move on. There has not been acknowledgement from the British side yet. And the overeager nationalism/lack of education of the average Indian on the internet makes matters worse.
author: winter prince

text:
¬†@Kyle Jones¬† totally agreed. but would they have been able to successfully rule a country like India from so far away? They were already running short on manpower trying to hold the urban areas of China. India is much more difficult than China, and the Japanese had no experience with countries like it. At most it would have been a puppet government, and that too would change.

Change is the currency of history, and I don't think nations like Germany or Japan ever had tje power to spell a real danger to the world in any manner. They lacked the manpower.

The british could only control India because of their hands off, uninvolved approach, and because of their civil service. The axis patently ruled through the army, which would have been unable to manage countries like the above two, especially the latter, having rapidly growing intelligentsia, and political forces to mobilize people in partisan suplort if the need arose.
author: winter prince

text:
¬†@Kyle Jones¬† I don't know what gave you that idea, but I don't think that at all! I took a different view from yours on some specific issues we discussed, but that is only a small part of my view on the west! Realistically speaking, we are more worried about China because the present matters more than the past. And at the end of it, we are all fat, greedy bastards, although some of us are sometimes able to rise above it.

Been fun chatting too! Take care!
author: winter prince

text:
¬†@Kyle Jones¬† oh and forgot to respond to the russia issue. Yeah, they do engage in proxy wars now. It's almost as if putin is salty and trying to give west the villain it has always portrayed russia as. It's an uncomfortable truth, but the west does regard russia like a looming danger, a strange, dark, looming place(paraphrasing from white tiger).

About UK, yes, UK is a special case. Even during colonial times brits were fond of india. Now UK and South Korea are among the only major countries to have a positive image of India.
The rest of the west is a different story. You see, media is the propaganda maker in a liberal state, and unlike theory, it sometimes acts with one mind, with an incredible bias. Much credit of the fall of the USSR can be attributed to the US media/intelligentsia, other than the american state, and the misdeeds of the russian state itself. The media is supposed to act like a witness, but it acts like a really really provincial judge(including Indian media), and western media for the most part has an incredible bias against India. And media is what controls the academia in our days.
As Noam Chomsky said. Most journalists are honest, and they try to do their duty impartially. However, they still reach biased consensuses at the end of the day. Because if you are that much of a dissenter, you are never going to reach the station of a journalist. Liberal society works by censorship(not saying liberal society is bad or anything).

text:
No.. The problem with this graph is that it does not indicate where the actual CO2 is finally emitted.. So it has countries like Australia and Canada as major producers.. But most of the CO2 from Canada and Australia gets emitted in countries that import Australian and Canadian exports like Coal and Oil..  Australia is the largest exporter of Coal in the world and it also takes a lot of energy to mine and transport that coal to the ports.. But that same coal has been used extensively in history, first by the UK and then by Japan and now By China with recent growing demand from India.. But it seems the ""responsibility"" for the emissions is being placed upon the countries that are the source of the Coal and Oil.. 



Countries like Australia and Canada are also major exporters of minerals like Iron ore.. The mining and transport of millions of tones of these metals and minerals to importing nations takes a huge amount of carbon emitting fuels, predominantly diesel.. So large emissions in mining nations like Australia and Canada does not come from Australians and Canadians personal use of these fuels.. Most of it comes from the mining and transport companies extracting and transporting millions of tons of ores for export to the end users in places like Europe and Asia..

text:
Be careful to understand the video. In 1983 India went beyond Belgium. This does not mean that India polluted as much as Belgium in 1983. This means that in 1983, Belgium had polluted as much as India since 1880 because Belgium is an industrialized country since the 19th century and not India. This video compares the total CO2 emissions since 1880, not current emissions.
Today, China is the biggest polluter of the world in front of the United States and India is third. China and India appear far behind in this video because they are countries that industrialized in the second half of the twentieth century, a century after the Westerners.

Indonesia pollutes today much more than France or Italy and yet, she is not even in the top 20 for the same reasons.


In fact, Europeans pollute less today than in 1990 while Chinese and Indians have multiplied their pollution by 5 in the same time. This is normal because of their population but I specify it anyway because the video could give the wrong idea that European countries are still today the biggest polluters in the world.


https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_carbon_dioxide_emissions

Great video anyway, thanks!
(And poor African countries that pollute almost nothing and who are the first victims of global warming...)

text:
The countries are counted as regions of the world in this video. Whether a region/territory is sovereign or not makes no difference to the fact it creates emissions. There IS a question of blame for those emissions during such periods of non-sovereignty, but this video is about statistics, not about assigning culpability. 

Failure to use the correct flags is a matter to take up with the video maker I guess. 


Britain's tally of CO2 does not include it's colonies at any point in the vid. All that CO2 built up by 1880 was created on the British mainland. As you probably learned in school, Britain was the world's first industrialised nation and had been burning fossil fuels on a massive scale since the mid 18th century. By the middle of the 19th century Britain had huge urbanised cities, steam powered industries and a vast network of railways whilst most nations were still pissing about with horses and waterwheels.


So they had quite the head start on screwing the planet up, basically.
